item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment:
I kept coming back to this over and over thinking I was missing something, but there just isn't much here. The draft isn't interesting as the best choice is usually obvious, and denying cards to your opponents is rarely useful.
I'd rather play a simpler, more immediately fun game if we're looking to fill a half-hour, or just sit down for a longer game that fully realizes all of 7 Wonders' civilization building potential. This is lost somewhere in no-mans-land.

item.name: Acquire
item.comment: A classic way ahead of its time. While it's been outshone by other excellent stockholding games, Acquire's cascading spatial mergers still manage to be compelling after nearly [i]sixty years[/i]. This is easily Sackson's best design.

item.name: Age of Steam
item.comment:
A brutal, incessant tightrope walk to financial viability driven by a route building system that feels distinct from other train games due to the exclusivity of track segments. Age of Steam is downright malevolent, but in a sort of uplifting, encouraging way: I always get the sense that it wants desperately for me to play at my highest ability, and I will continue failing to meet its expectations.
The mean-streak can occasionally be overbearing rather than endearing though. Everyone always seems one bad delivery away from utter ruin, and it takes dedicated, prolonged, [i]stressful[/i] attention to avoid that possibility.
I know this will sound stupid to the legions of AoS fans that have sunk thousands upon thousands of games into what is clearly a very robust system, but I'm not entirely convinced that the turn order actions are tuned quite right: it sometimes feels like you're just bidding for Loco. I get that their inherent imbalance is a chief source of bidding incentive, but in my limited experience it feels disproportionately warping. The auction can also get a little weird in the last round, with everyone just shoving stacks and the production/pass actions becoming literally useless.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment:
A clean, mean machine that creates serious tension with scarce resources and small worker pools, but sometimes gets mired in heads-down hand analysis.
Agricola is a good reminder of what made worker placement so compelling in the first place; you need five things, you have three guys, and you can only place [i]one of them[/i] before your loathsome and greedy opponents are set loose on all this precious stuff. What do you need most?

item.name: Air, Land, & Sea
item.comment: A Battle Line imitator that smothers its one innovative mechanic. When one swingy card power can dramatically shift the state of the battle on multiple fronts, getting a sense of when you are in a losing position and should withdraw becomes excessively opaque.

item.name: Alchemists
item.comment:
Standard matrix-based deduction stapled to a euro game. Nothing significant seems to be gained from the marriage, but much is lost in burying an otherwise approachable puzzle under a mountain of rules. Planet X is still king in this category.
Our first two games were also handily won by whatever player purchased the artifact that lets you lose only one ingredient per test. I'm sure it's not actually overpowered, but it was disproportionately game warping for us.

item.name: Amun-Re
item.comment: I adore the bifurcated auction structure where your precious developed plots are gleefully sold off to your opponents in the second round, but the high-variance power cards end up being fatally unpredictable. I might come back to this to try out a variant with less luck.

item.name: Antiquity
item.comment:
The Splotteriest Splotter of them all. Prickly as a porcupine, overflowing with bits, and almost nihilistic in its pessimism. Spiritually closer to Roads & Boats/FCM than to Indonesia/TGZ in its emphasis on competing action efficiencies rather than affecting a shared incentive space.
Antiquity is a fairly solitaire affair in the early game, but the level of detail achieved during the first few rounds is impressive despite that. There is a lovely intersection of tight resource management, emergent worker placement, and polyomino puzzling, with deeply integrated opportunity costs between each of these systems.
Once players are forced to expand, however, Antiquity’s base-building roots begin to turn outwards to the shared board, and reading the state of your opponent’s engine becomes vital for good play all the way to the end of the game. This "turning out" narrative is satisfying, especially when so many shared board euros move in exactly the opposite direction.
The variable and flexible win conditions are seemingly brilliant but perhaps fatally imbalanced (is Santa Maria useful as anything other than a foot-shooting device?). Player positions are more fluid than I expected as cathedrals are razed and rebuilt to suit the current game state, but the inherent tempo of the system is rather opaque for the first few games, so it is very clear to me that a player with enough experience with the subtleties of Antiquity’s pacing will simply beat a more inexperienced player every time, even accounting for perfect tactical reads.
Despite that, I like this system quite a lot, and assuming all the players at the table are on equal footing, there’s a striking game in here.

item.name: Apples to Apples
item.comment: Falls into the same trap Cards Against Humanity does, in that it doesn't allow players to be funny in their own way, they have to pick a prewritten card. It's a little better than CAH though for having simpler answers that are more open to interpretation, so you can find your own humor in them.

item.name: Arboretum
item.comment:
An unassuming menace: these lovely little trees won't hesitate to shove your brain through a wood chipper. The balance between playing your trees for points and hoarding your trees for the right to score your points is an agonizing central conflict, and relies on careful, studious card counting.
The act of playing your trees into a grid to score points is a far less interesting process than the hand-management fight though, requiring pretty much the same layout for every game. It isn't fatal to the experience, but it adds some complexity for little gain.
There is quite a lot of game in this box for two players. Avoid playing with more due to downtime.

item.name: Argent: The Consortium
item.comment:
An adventurous and strikingly aggressive take on worker placement with a ridiculous end game scoring system and engine-building effects that are unabashedly and dazzlingly game-warping (think Chudyk).
Argent isn’t elegant, it isn’t focused, and I’m not sure how much control someone would really have given the heaping servings of chaos, but the whole experience is so immediately fun that I don’t know if I care. I can’t believe it, but you win anime game.

item.name: Arkadia
item.comment:
Another elegant and compelling interactive euro from this era. Cleverly blends spatial puzzling, area control, tempo management, and stock holding.
Reef Encounter is a clear parallel, and might offer a little more strategic depth, but Arkadia plays faster and feels more focused, so they both can stay!

item.name: Arkham Horror: The Card Game
item.comment: I love that it doesn't take itself too seriously and that it allows for a decent amount of roleplaying. Rating may change as I experiment with more scenarios and campaigns.

item.name: Ascension: Deckbuilding Game
item.comment: It's creative debts to Dominion are obvious, and when compared to Dominion's strategic elegance Ascension can feel a little shallow and overly tactical, but I find myself oddly charmed by it. There is a far greater emphasis on card combos in this box, and these interactions are just interesting enough to keep my attention but not so complex as to feel like Ascension is trying to emulate Magic. This sits comfortably in some mysterious, relaxing sweet spot where my brain can wind-down without turning off. I also admire the striking and consistent art style; it's amazing how far that goes in selling me on a card game.

item.name: Azul
item.comment: There is some tactical play allowed by denying your opponents the tiles they want, but the main puzzle is just too simple to be interesting. I also think the plain red and blue tiles stick out like sore thumbs against the beautiful patterned designs, and it degrades the otherwise stellar aesthetics by a surprising amount.

item.name: Babylonia
item.comment:
I feel like I finally understand Babylonia after getting a chance to play Samurai. Forget the comparisons to Through the Desert or Tigris or Taj Mahal; in my mind Babylonia is Samurai 2, and it improved upon the design so much as to completely antiquate its predecessor.
The tile laying is more strategic due to the ziggurat bonuses and the need for strong look-ahead to create connected groups, and the scoring has been made far more granular to avoid Samurai’s unsatisfying reliance on thin tie-breakers. This is a reassuring display of Knizia’s continuing insight as a designer.

item.name: Barrage
item.comment:
It’s similarities to Terra Mystica are so pervasive as to be distracting, and unfortunately Barrage does nothing to convince me that it’s worth playing over its progenitor. I can already get my fix of positional posturing, engine-building, and high-latency resource management without the burden of a sluggish worker-placement framework and dreary theme.
I will say that despite the dark color palette the quality of the artwork is very high, with one hilariously glaring exception: the actual game board itself. It’s perhaps the most important component in the whole box, and it is the only one that is actively ugly. Bravo.

item.name: Baseball Highlights: 2045
item.comment:
Bafflingly, offensively ugly; maybe the ugliest game I've ever played. There is some soft charm to be found in bad or boring board game art, but not here: it's simply hideous.
Mechanically, Baseball Highlights is a bit sluggish. The tit-for-tat counter-play during the innings feels pretty automatic and lacking in any sort of tension, and the randomized card market makes synergies and strategic planning almost impossible. I also kind of hate the standard game's insistence on playing three pointless pre-games before the World Series, with the results determining nothing other than home field advantage.

item.name: Battle Line
item.comment: Sickeningly tight. Part poker, part deduction, part area control. Accessible and brilliant.

item.name: Beowulf: The Legend
item.comment:
Lighthearted and dramatic storytelling/auction game that captures the source material's theme of braggadocious machismo quite vividly.
I just don't care for how lenient the risk-taking mechanic feels: it's hard to push your luck too far, and the penalty for doing so is usually minimal, especially when the alternative of simply bowing out of an auction is a guaranteed late reward that may be just as bad if not worse. Pushing for risks just feels like too much of a non-decision in many rounds, and it makes the auctions devolve quickly into coin-flips where most of the cards that end up on the table aren't from players' carefully managed hands, but just randomly drawn from the top of the deck. Maybe it should have just been one card per risk?

item.name: Billabong
item.comment:
An austere racing game that feels like it should be more explosive than it is. The possibility of stringing together a huge, complicated series of hops to fling a pawn halfway across the circuit is intoxicating, but sacrificing your team's cohesion in the process makes these moves riskier than they first appear. This is especially true as your pawns begin crossing the finish line and your opportunities to leech off of your opponents inevitably dry up. Billabong has one tenet: stay together or die. I've always been deeply frustrated by games where the move that is [i]good[/i] and the move that is [i]fun[/i] aren't, in fact, the same move, and this is a glaring example.
This forced conservatism and the constant need for tactical reconsideration as the board changes from turn to turn makes Billabong a very slow game. What should be a thirty minute filler is an hour-plus slog. Add in the fact that the endgame can devolve into weird kingmaking situations from players who are not in contention makes Billabong's overstayed welcome even more distasteful.

item.name: Bios: Genesis
item.comment:
The complexity to size ratio is off the charts here; the rules overhead is beyond prohibitive. The real shame is that the general game-flow is pretty intuitive, but parsing that out from the rules as written is painful. This could have benefitted heavily from some teaching aides or a front-loaded play summary or a split rulebook system ala Root. The rulebook just isn't great for learning or for reference.
But once that intuitive foundation has been parsed out, the experience is dramatic and humbling and monumental. This almost certainly fails as a purely competitive game, but it tells an immense, rich story.
My thoughts will likely evolve (ha) as I explore more of Phil's designs, especially the rest of this series.

item.name: Blokus
item.comment: It's an interesting puzzle. Not a fan of the bizarre variants that require exchanging control of a neutral color. I may be subconsciously writing Blokus off because of how ubiquitous it is. Needs more plays.

item.name: Blood Rage
item.comment:
Another case of wanting to like it more than I do. What I want is a raucous, stompy game that lives up to a name like "Blood Rage", but instead this just sort of hobbles along with slow drafts, often anticlimactic battles, and a lot of private upgrade management.
People like to bring up runaway leader problems for games that don't deserve it, but this is a rare exception where I think the critique is justified. There is almost no compensation given to losing armies in regards to board state or action economy, and the winners are unilaterally rewarded with increases in both. Early pillage winners can just feel unstoppable at times. When every player is perfectly checking the power of every other player the system works, but the balance is too delicate.
The minis also add to the cost but don't add to the game, and the depiction of women in an exclusively female tribe all clad in fur bikinis feels really slimy for a game that came out in 2015. There's no excuse for that kind of stuff anymore.

item.name: Blue Moon City
item.comment:
Blue Moon City is a fast old-school euro that has been given an unbelievably beautiful new coat of paint in the CMON edition. The artwork is unabashedly surreal and totally unique for a board game; this little world gives me the same fantastical gut-spin as Beksinski, Dali, or Remedios Varo. The minis also fit right in and don't feel superfluous at all to me! This is simply a perfect production. Gorgeous.
The game itself is also surprisingly tactile, with good shared incentive patterns and meaningful spatial restrictions on the board. The static win condition is a refreshing departure from the standard point-conversion I was expecting, and it kept the game brutally focused, almost race-like. I'm a little worried by how close each of my games have been, but until this proves to be an issue Blue Moon City is some more solid heads-up euro goodness from Knizia.
I will say that the brown, gray, and black cards / tiles are almost indistinguishable in the new edition, its the one fault I have with the visual design.

item.name: Blue Moon Legends
item.comment:
Deflating; I was expecting a lot out of this too. The card play felt lacking in variability and emergent combos, and the battles seemed a little anticlimactic, maybe even outright boring. The decks included in the box also felt constrained by their respective (and rather uninteresting) gimmicks.
The art is technically well made, something that can't be said for most card games, but the character design is often some flavor of goofy or hypersexualized, and so the thematic experience of Blue Moon ends up feeling disappointingly schlocky. The CMON edition of Blue Moon City thankfully moved away from this and did this world justice.
These dueling "TGC in a box" games always seem to suffer in the shadow of Magic, and none of them seem to make any effort to match Magic's level of nuance. I thought Knizia would be different, but this lackluster number-go-up tug-of-war attempt isn't it.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment: A riotous little trading game that only just outstays its welcome. While I enjoy the fixed-hand rule immensely, it is a constant battle not to let my Magic-addled brain ruffle my cards. I wish the third field wasn't so prohibitively expensive, it feels like a trap for new players more than anything.

item.name: Boomtown Bandits
item.comment:
A super lightweight game whose only point of interest is a paper thin bluffing mechanic between the haphazard and game-less real time shootouts.
I’m exhausted by all of these family-weight games that don’t put enough effort into their rulebook. If you have special cards with specific timings, it must be abundantly clear when these cards can be played without having to come to a niche site like BGG. I understand the urge to thin the rulebook as much as possible to lower the barrier of entry, but it comes at a huge cost. Leaving it up to the players to argue over best guesses (which will inevitably happen when someone is on the receiving end of a dubiously timed card effect) sucks a lot of the joy out of a game like this. The best the rulebook offers here is an unhelpful and childish reminder to its players to “just chill out and be cool lol”.
Boomtown Bandits’ most baffling misstep, however, is that it unnecessarily disqualifies itself from being a family game (or at least one with wide appeal) due to its mandatory brothel location card. So this is supposed to be a silly, real-time shouting contest for…who exactly? It shot itself squarely in the foot with that thematic choice.

item.name: The Bottle Imp
item.comment: An inversion of trick-taking that is wonderfully unintuitive.

item.name: Brass: Lancashire
item.comment: Rock solid euro/economic hybrid, with significant interdependency and entanglement between players and just enough meanness. I'm still unconvinced that the cards are a boon to the system, but I hope with time I will come to respect their tactical variance.

item.name: The Bridges of Shangri-La
item.comment: I'm not sure this has the depth I was promised. All three of my games have ended with scores so brutally tight that I'm doubting there are any dramatic or important decisions to be made at all. The transparent mutualism of Bridges is admirable though, and I desperately [i]want[/i] it to work, so I'm going to give it one more spin and see if the game is responsive to more aggression, but my hopes aren't that high.

item.name: Broom Service
item.comment: Filled with personality and warmth and good humor. Player positions are just transparent enough to make the bluffing feel meaningful, and carefully avoiding the ruinous possibility of your actions being done out of order is thrilling. It's just a wonderful time, and an exemplar of great family game design.

item.name: Bug
item.comment:
It is an undeniably gorgeous abstract design, but even after dozens of wins I'm still not sure I'm totally following the chain of cause and effect on the board. It's not that the rules are unclear, I just can't seem to develop a set of heuristics for analyzing board position or making good plays.
The results of many of my games of Bug feel strangely arbitrary. That probably means I don't get it. I'll keep throwing myself at this wall until something sticks.

item.name: Bumúntú
item.comment:
Fine little tactical abstract that is unfortunately bogged down by a laborious setup and some extraneous design elements.
The terse Reef Encounter-esque market manipulation isn't as dynamic as it first appears, as animals have a tendency to just stick around whatever value they were assigned during setup, and scoring for each type by majority/minority makes tile collection an unnecessarily calculational affair.
The set-collection categories also feel pretty unimaginative and further dilute the importance of the animal market, and the theme doesn't go far enough in capturing non-abstract gamers.

item.name: Bus
item.comment:
While its stark, utterly focused minimalism is admirable, the sheer potency of Bus's core systems create a final product that feels relentlessly sharp-edged and frigidly cold; metallic in nature.
A rare example of a game that I feel could be improved by [i]loosening[/i] up the design. Have a drink Bus, you need one.

item.name: Cairn
item.comment:
Grossly overproduced modern abstract that seems to have ignored or forgotten what makes great abstracts so great in the first place. The fiddly megalith powers have an annoying combo potential that undermines any sort of worthwhile look-ahead and they create a devastating snowball effect for any player that gets an early material advantage. Without the megaliths the flipping action tiles could have been a very satisfying and meaningfully incremental engine, but they’re quickly overwhelmed by the annoying modern need for a “unique” power buffet.
The graphic design is also a little hard to read at times, especially the totem colors.

item.name: Calico
item.comment: Inoffensive solitaire take-a-thing-place-a-thing. I slightly prefer it to Azul because the puzzle is a little more interesting.

item.name: Camel Up (Second Edition)
item.comment:
Camel Up is a charming and entertaining little betting game that doesn’t ask too much of its players, which makes it great for casual groups, families, or states of inebriation. Some races are definitely more exciting than others though, and if the dice come out in such a way as to hugely favor one camel over the others then the leg bets and end game bets can lose a lot of their tension. Dramatic comebacks or upsets are possible (and viscerally exciting when they do occur), but certainly not guaranteed, so there is some risk of having a bit of a dud game. It might have helped to have some way to directly place bets on second, third, and fourth place rankings, so there's still something to spar over even with an obvious winner or an obvious loser. I’m also a bit disappointed with how variable the effect of the crazy camels can be; they are an inspired mechanic, but I feel like I’ve seen too many races where their effect is negligible.
When Camel Up hits, it hits hard. I just wish it hit every time.
Also, while the production is obviously evocative, it dangerously treads the line between toy and game with the obstructive pop-up palm trees and the loaf-pinching plastic pyramid. Maybe I’m being stuffy, but these thematic gimmicks feel a little wasteful when more sustainable alternatives could have easily sufficed, like pulling dice from a bag. Oh well, at least it gets people excited to play.

item.name: Can't Stop
item.comment: As long as a group can accept the fact that there is almost no game in here and really lean into the drama it can be good fun.

item.name: Candy Land
item.comment: Even tic-tac-toe has more going for it as a simple tool for teaching young kids the concepts of turn-taking and look-ahead without sucking away more than 2 minutes of your precious time on this good green Earth.

item.name: Cannes: Stars, Scripts and Screens
item.comment:
Primarily a resource-conversion logistics game with some interesting topological constraints in the map building, but it ends [i]way[/i] too soon for any of that to matter, and the random tile draw can arbitrarily give someone an advantage in accessing vitally important and scarce secondary producers.
This feels like an earnest, if somewhat underdeveloped predecessor to Roads & Boats, but it actually released three years after! I'm unsure how to feel about Cannes given that fact, and I feel doubly conflicted on it because Neuland exists, which to me delivers a more meaningful (and luckless) logistics experience in a similar timeframe. Misstep from the Splotter boys.
Also, while Splotter's predilection towards satire and cynicism is usually appreciated, given the recent exposure of Hollywood's sickening treatment of women in the industry, Cannes' Old Boys Club mechanic feels retrospectively tone-deaf and nauseating.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment: Easy to learn, pretty to look at, and surprisingly interactive. The central mechanic of competing ownership of tile features turns a seemingly cute little tile laying game into a wonderful, aggressive melee. Improved with "strategic variant" with a hand of three tiles.

item.name: Carcassonne Big Box 6
item.comment: Bad value for the money. Carcassonne is a fantastic game with a single essential expansion: Inns & Cathedrals. Everything else in this box is forgettable at best and actively detrimental to the game at worst. The amount of empty space in the box is ridiculous even by "big box" standards. Not worth the MSRP at all.

item.name: Carcassonne: Corn Circles II
item.comment: Damningly innocuous.

item.name: Carcassonne: Expansion 1 – Inns & Cathedrals
item.comment: Carcassonne's only (yes, only!) worthwhile expansion. The big meeple enhances Carcassonne's central interactive mechanic (ownership fights), and the inns make up for weak roads in the base game. I'll never play without this.

item.name: Carcassonne: Expansion 2 – Traders & Builders
item.comment:
The goods tiles don't fit into Carcassonne at all for me; it feels like an oversimplified system from another game. Ownership fights over cities were already tense, they didn't need the help of a crude set collection mechanic.
The builders, by allowing double turns, create downtime that was usually (and thankfully) absent from the base game, and the pigs just enhance a feature that was already balanced, if they end up doing anything at all.
Carcassonne doesn't need any of this.

item.name: Carcassonne: Mage & Witch
item.comment: Fiddly and opaque in ways not conducive to Carcassonne's simplicity, and thematically out of place.

item.name: Carcassonne: The Ferries
item.comment: Unforgivably fiddly for a game of Carcassonne, and too unpredictable in its effect on road scoring.

item.name: Carcassonne: The Flying Machines
item.comment: Undermines the central mechanic of Carcassonne by sometimes having carefully planned tile ownership stolen by a die roll.

item.name: Carcassonne: The Gold Mines
item.comment:
The Carcassonne mini expansion I hate the least. There is at least some decision making with the placement of gold bars, and they can occasionally shift the course of a conflict on the board. The increasing value of the bars is a little annoying to me, I would have preferred if they provided static VP.
Not needed, but not actively detrimental to the game; that's a feat in itself for these modules.

item.name: Carcassonne: The Messengers
item.comment: Pointless little random bonuses given out for landing on multiples of 5 (why 5 again?) on the score track. Superfluous and antithetical to Carcassonne's focus on a shared board.

item.name: Carcassonne: The Robbers
item.comment:
Moving the robber around the score board actively sabotaged our game because of how frustratingly similar the meeple looks to the one used for tracking your score; we spent several turns moving the wrong meeple, and realized it far too late to rewind the game state.
We called it a wash and tried again to give the expansion a fair shake, and we did manage to get through a whole (painstaking) game without any mistakes in robber movement. For our efforts we were handsomely rewarded with an expansion experience that truly pushes the boundaries of pointlessness.
Two games of Carcassonne ruined in different ways. Quite an accomplishment.

item.name: Cards Against Humanity
item.comment:
Player creativity and personality can't shine through because all the answers and jokes are prewritten. A game like this should allow players to be themselves and respond to a group's sense of humor: let players actually be funny on their own.
Quiplash is king.

item.name: Carson City
item.comment:
I was a little let down by Carson City after falling so hard for George’s other mechanism mish-mash game Ginkgopolis. While that felt like more than the sum of its parts, Carson City just feels…mushy. A little role selection, a little worker placement, a little Caylus-style building system, a little Santiago-style board networking, and a little dice rolling to add variety. It all works fine, but the intersection isn’t particularly lively or inspired.
I might revisit this again to see if my feelings change, but only if someone else suggested it.

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy
item.comment:
A sluggish and dull game of point conversion that left so little of an impression that I'm having a hard time thinking of anything to say about it.
The variations in the duchies looked kind of interesting I guess?

item.name: CATAN
item.comment: It's a fun, simple, evergreen game that served as my primary gateway to the hobby (how woefully predictable). Given its popularity, I'm surprised more games I've played haven't tried to emulate the same kind of fast one-on-one trades that Catan relies on. "Wood for a sheep?".

item.name: Catan: Cities & Knights
item.comment:
Shoves a completely unnecessary amount of complexity into Catan, and draws attention away from the central mechanic that made Catan fun in the first place: trading.
If you want a more complex eurogame, go play a more complex eurogame; don't try and force Catan to be something it isn't. This is the absolute worst kind of expansion.

item.name: Catan: Seafarers
item.comment: Great expansion. Adds some needed breadth without much additional depth. Most of the scenarios are fine but not great.

item.name: Caverna: The Cave Farmers
item.comment: After some more experience with Agricola I may need to revisit Caverna with fresh eyes. While I am swooned by Agricola's tightness, I sometimes find myself wanting to return to the comparatively generous, relaxed farm-building experience of Caverna.

item.name: Caylus
item.comment:
Mean-spirited and mentally exhausting. With Caylus I once again find myself in the awkward position of admitting that the game that "invented" a mechanic (justice for Bus) is simply better than most of its vastly more popular imitators. I don't [i]want[/i] to be an insufferable cult-of-the-old contrarian, really I don't! But the worker placement here is just wonderfully crunchy and brutally interactive: building ownership; increasing assignment cost to place workers as players pass; provost positioning; considerations of round length and game length. Every element makes every placement of every worker a delightfully tortuous exercise.
However, all of these overlapping mechanical considerations make decisions slow, and paired with its intrinsic pacing Caylus becomes quite a long game. Not overlong mind you, the hours seem to fly by during play, but the experience is uniquely taxing.

item.name: Celebrities
item.comment:
The king of all party games. Yes this is more of a framework than a game in itself, but this system can be modified to fit [i]any[/i] context.
That openness is essential for me, so I'm not a fan of the fully produced, prepackaged versions of this that have come around like Time's Up! or Monikers. They're just too rigid in their celebrity choices and round structure, so the game loses its remarkable versatility. Just have everyone write down some names (or places or things or anything) and toss them in a bowl.

item.name: Cheating Moth
item.comment:
A surprisingly poignant little demonstration of the thrill of breaking unconscious taboos in gaming. Throw that card (that precious unsleeved card) on the floor or stuff it into your pockets or step on it with your shoe. Slay the oh so sacred cow!
This is very much a group-dependent game though, and requires everyone involved to buy in to the experience and play in good faith (not cheating away cards too quickly and admitting when you've been caught). Maybe that smacks too much of "you can cheat but you can't [i]cheat[/i] cheat" for some people, but if a group is on board and has a good sense of humor there are few other games that are as earnestly irreverent.

item.name: Chess
item.comment: I can't not respect it, but after a lifetime of casual play and more than a few attempts to test my mettle online, I simply have no desire to pick this up again. It punishes blunders so decisively, with so much giddy exuberance, that a good game of Chess is measured far more by the absence of mistakes than the presence of skill. My mind simply doesn't enjoy this type of play environment.

item.name: Chicago Express
item.comment:
Sleek design that enables some truly brutal maneuvering; it's amazing that Bohrer managed to so effortlessly squeeze the essence of a train game into such a refined, breakneck package.
The necessity of well-timed cooperation and defection clearly relies on thoughtful, intentioned play from all players, so I'm constantly worrying that my dumb ass is bringing down the experience, but if I can ignore those voices long enough Chicago Express is a grand old time!

item.name: Citadels
item.comment: Went on just a tad longer than it should have for what it was, and the building/economy/set-collection part of the game was pretty bland. I’ll experiment with the short game variant and see if that improves the experience, because the hidden role selection system was interesting.

item.name: Clank!: A Deck-Building Adventure
item.comment: Mildly swashbuckling deck builder with far too much variance to stay interesting.

item.name: Clans
item.comment:
Intense, thought provoking abstract with a surprising amount of bluff and subterfuge, which gives it a warm personality that many classic euro-abstracts lack.
After playing at every count, I think it’s best at 3: the balance between player colors and “neutral” colors is perfect. 4 feels like the weakest player count by far; the incentives become “too” overlapped and it can be too chaotic.

item.name: Clippers
item.comment:
Very cube-rails-esque. Investing in locations on the board instead of into the companies themselves is a fascinating inversion, as is the eschewing of any sort of share auction in favor of an action card draft at the start of each round. The dilemma between securing endgame positions and chasing after those sweet sweet short term payouts is also compelling.
The components do suck though; the microscopic chits should be replaced by cubes immediately.

item.name: Clue
item.comment:
The only classic family board game that was any good. As shocking as it may sound, the deduction in here was actually quite subtle. Good players care just as much about other players' turns as their own, and constructing questions to maximally eliminate possibilities took some thought. There was even some maneuvering allowed in tracking which cards you had shown to the other players to exploit any of their redundant suggestions.
Of course, the capricious noise of the dice movement ruins all of this good stuff. Maybe one day I'll come back and try the dice-less variants that get thrown around here, but with so many good modern deduction games vying for attention, I'm not sure that day will ever come.

item.name: Cockroach Poker
item.comment: The purity of the bluffing (this card is X, but it's Y) felt almost laughably simple at first, but it manages to get pretty tricky as the game progresses and players inch towards a loss condition.

item.name: Codenames
item.comment: Where's the party? Codenames is a rather dry word-guessing game where most of players' time is spent in total silence, and it isn't mechanically interesting enough to make up for that.

item.name: Coloretto
item.comment: There is some game in here, but there may be too much of a positional problem with Coloretto: a weak player can end up unintentionally gifting points to the player on their left, and the scores are usually close enough that it matters. For a game that is [i]this[/i] much of a lightweight filler, requiring such a delicate skill balance between 4+ players is a tough sell.

item.name: Concordia
item.comment:
Smooth-as-glass design, but almost entirely noninteractive save for some cursory, usually incidental interference. The interweaving of the cards into the map and goods system and turn structure is all meticulously refined, so its a shame that at its core Concordia is just another heads-down optimizer game that exists in the highly competitive 90-minute time slot.
Be warned, though I personally enjoy the deck-building score system, I have seen new players bounce off of it completely due to its opaqueness and reliance on light memorization, so it can be a hurdle.

item.name: Condottiere
item.comment: Constantly produces moments of complex bluffing, tactical counter play and dramatic underdog victories, all with just a few small components.

item.name: Container
item.comment:
Perhaps the purest economic game I’ve played; inspiring for producing such intensity of play from such a minimalist rule set. The lack of guardrails and level of mutualism in Container’s economy is all fascinating of course, but in a dry, abstract, “suits shaking hands in a boardroom” sort of way. When compared to my other favorite auction games like Modern Art or Chicago Express, which are [i]exciting[/i] and even sardonic, Container feels morose. Beige.
The only gripe I have with the rules system is the strange and hard-to-explain exception of being forced to dump your 5/10 containers if they’re tied with another color. I understand the strategic intent of the rule, but it’s an inelegant sticking point that I’m not sure is worth the effort.
I also much prefer the short variant; very little seems to be lost by taking a few containers out of the supply, but everything is gained by getting Container in under 70 minutes.

item.name: Cosmic Frog
item.comment: Admirably self assured in its absurdity and excess. Tile management in the vault is a little too cerebral for how intentionally meatheaded the rest of the game is, but that's kind of my only gripe with the system. Cosmic Frog is a refreshing and intensely gorgeous homage to old-school beat-em-up game design. More games like this need to be made.

item.name: The Crew: The Quest for Planet Nine
item.comment:
Yet another limited communication coop that just isn’t specific enough about its communication limits in the rulebook. I’m so tired of playing games like these for the first time, forming an opinion of the experience, then coming to BGG and discovering that the community interpretation of these limits is almost entirely opposite of what is written in the rules.
The publisher has even released an official statement that (in my opinion) directly contradicts the printed rulebook. So fine, I’ll try this again with the intended rule set, but this type of unnecessary ambiguity always sours the experience for me.

item.name: Cribbage
item.comment:
An absolute classic card game that is just too easy to master. With just a few hours of hand analysis in a digital version the discard patterns become painfully obvious, and with very little effort you can learn to approximate perfect play. At that point Cribbage becomes a drawn out coin flip.
I have deep, fond memories of playing Cribbage with my family, but its decision space is depressingly small.

item.name: Cryptid
item.comment: I like that all the relevant information is presented on a shared board, so it avoids the quiet, private spreadsheet studying that Clue, Sleuth, and even my beloved Planet X fall into at times. The deduction is a little simpler as a result, but the experience is far more open and social.

item.name: Cubitos
item.comment:
This really is just Quacks: the Dice Game, but luckily for Mr. Clair I'm willing to forgive the copied homework because I'm a primitive brute who enjoys throwing fistfuls of colored cubes more than pulling chits out of a bag.
I do wish that there was some sort of interaction via blocking on the board though. I'll try out some of the proposed variants on here, hopefully it'll only improve an already endearing game.

item.name: Curious Cargo
item.comment:
Refreshingly unforgiving spatial and tempo puzzle. The inherent variance in the tile supply and truck deck, paired with the ability to "cut" or redirect pipe segments easily by layering tiles makes Curious Cargo a game of wild, seat-of-your-pants organization and reorganization.
This doesn't come naturally to every player, and AP can become an issue in this regard. This can be alleviated somewhat by simultaneous construction phases, but then actions can become hard to audit. Giving each player a set of "counting tokens" for tracking actions is extremely helpful for this.

item.name: Decrypto
item.comment:
Keeping the same words over multiple rounds is an interesting twist on most word-guessing games, and this is probably the best of that bunch. It does end up having similar problems though: things can slow down while the clue giver is thinking, and because of the additional consideration of the opposing team's knowledge it can slow down quite a lot.
I also happen to be shockingly bad at this one, so I'm sorry to anyone who happens to get teamed up with me.

item.name: Dixit
item.comment: Beautiful and easygoing, with a clever little central mechanism, but loses its luster [i]fast[/i]. The moment you run out of new cards to see, the game is over. Dixit can only possibly stay interesting with a constant stream of expansion material that just isn't worth the price of admission.

item.name: Die Dolmengötter
item.comment: Thorny shared incentives and compelling dilemmas regarding timing, action efficiency, and scoring insurance delivered in a fiery, whiplash-inducing half hour. I think this might be one of the only games with a board that can actually go toe-to-toe with card games as a [i]true[/i] filler for four. Part of me does crave a little more arc to the experience, so I'm excited to try the "block cycling" variant and seeing what extra oomph there is to be found in a slightly longer game.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment: Blew my mind when I first played it. Building and playing a deck at the same time was a revelation to me, and while its brilliance has faded somewhat after hundreds of plays, this still remains my favorite deckbuilder. The static market gives Dominion a potent strategic edge that many of its successors lack, and victory points clogging up your deck is a divisive tension that I enjoy. The art truly ([i]truly[/i]) sucks, but mechanically this is still king of the hill.

item.name: Dominion (Second Edition) Big Box
item.comment: Good value for the money, and the changes in the second edition improve the base game. But it's almost funny how ugly this box is. I thought the image of the two individual game boxes was a placeholder for selling the game in online stores, but it's actually printed on the box. I laughed out loud when I opened the package. It's so deeply hideous that I just can't bring myself to use this for its intended purpose. You know, a big box.

item.name: Dominion: Intrigue
item.comment: Good pool of cards, I basically consider it part of the base set at this point. But the art is just as bad as in the original set, and in some cases even manages to exceed the base game's high standard for lack of depth and grotesquely misshapen heads.

item.name: Dune: A Game of Conquest and Diplomacy
item.comment:
With all the assorted bells and whistles of the original design stripped away, I came to the surprising realization that I don’t actually enjoy the original Dune as a war/area control game, and that the effort to isolate those elements of the design (a seemingly admirable task) ended up entirely missing the point. All I wanted were my bells and whistles back.
Just play Dune. Sink into that game space with all its retro campiness and baffling thematic edge cases. Don’t use this as any sort of stepping stone; take the full plunge.

item.name: DVONN
item.comment: Amazingly elegant game of connectivity and defensive maneuvering; this gracefully turns your mind over in its hands, gently firing neurons in regions few other games dare to tread. Learning to recognize the elimination of your own pieces as both a threat and a weapon requires a wonderful shift in perspective.

item.name: Elements
item.comment: How the hell is it still possible to find new, exciting games with just a few numbered cards? Creating such a delicate atmosphere of risk management and bluff with a system [i]this[/i] skeletal is truly inspiring.

item.name: Eminent Domain
item.comment: A game killed by comparison: a slower Race for the Galaxy; a less strategically variable Dominion; a Glory to Rome with all the bombastic soul taken out. Eminent Domain is certainly a [i]functional[/i] game, but that should come as no surprise given how closely it sought to emulate those other, greater games. I can only describe it as derivative, as harsh as that sounds.

item.name: The Estates
item.comment:
While undeniably dynamic and elegant in its design and presentation, I just can't bring myself to love The Estates. The capricious uncertainty of property values overwhelms any sort of control I feel I have over the system, even accounting for the potential of strained alliance between players: the point values are just too swingy and the fate of your investment too opaque and the ownership of buildings too zero-sum. While many auction games suffer from overly-transparent lot values, The Estates is an interesting reminder that the opposite is also true.
It's also a little too mean for its own good, but I may just feel that way because I frequently lose. I'd play Modern Art over this every time.

item.name: Ethnos
item.comment:
Ethnos had me under its snappy spell for a game or two, but my opinion of it has continued to erode with each subsequent play. The whole game absolutely [i]depends[/i] on the card market being filled by the players to make any impactful decisions with your hand (what region to play for, what power to build towards), but the card draw is so pitiful and building decent bands is such a slow process that excess cards are rarely dumped, and Ethnos usually ends up devolving into a painfully luck driven top-decking game of Go Fish.
What is truly baffling though is the decision to create two (two!) different special abilities that further undermine the essential card dumping mechanic (Centaurs and Elves). They all but guarantee the draw-pass syndrome that makes Ethnos so disappointing, and their presence is so detrimental to the game that I would urge simply throwing them out.

item.name: Evolution: Climate
item.comment: Has some really nice synergistic tableau building with a small dose of player interaction. The tug-of-war and arms-race effects of evolutionary adaptations is felt strongly, and the food supply is refreshingly scarce.

item.name: Factory Fun
item.comment: Hopelessly heads-down and weirdly complex in all the wrong places (pipe pricing). Not even redeemable as a solo puzzle with all the hundreds of video games that do this type of logistic-spatial problem solving with more depth and less headache.

item.name: Fantasy Realms
item.comment:
A neat little deck of cards that is somewhat fun to explore, but with far too little control or range to make this a filler I want to return to. The card game equivalent of a bright and flashy Vegas slot machine.
Maybe if there was a way to deny cards to your opponents without having to keep them in your hand (an opportunity cost that is almost never worth it) there could be enough interaction here to make this all interesting. Alas.

item.name: A Feast for Odin
item.comment:
The last heavy solitaire resource shuffler you’ll ever need, and the conceptual “conclusion” to Rosenburg’s catalog.
There are elements from every one of his popular designs in here, and admittedly AFFO is on the verge of bursting at the seams, but somewhere in the gluttonous sprawl lies a generous and surprisingly thematic game that continues to please me with its interlocking spatial subtleties.

item.name: A Feast for Odin: The Norwegians
item.comment:
As close to perfect as an expansion can get: this is how the base game should have been (and I like base AFFO).
Modular action boards beautifully balance the game across player counts and make Odin feel overall less bloated, the reworking of the occupation system adds more tactical variety to the card management and makes dud effects feel less deflating, and the new exploration islands and special good tiles are wonderful, of course.
If Odin was ever re-released as a revised edition, it should without question integrate the Norwegians into the base game; it's that essential.

item.name: Fields of Arle
item.comment: It's pacing is good and player strategies can be fairly divergent, but it's a little too similar to Rosenburg's other resource shufflers to justify a place in my collection. The vehicles and buildings aren't enough to make this feel distinct, and most of those other games scale well enough to two players. It's also a little silly that a game specifically designed for two players didn't have its action board readable by both players sitting across from one another. Baffling design choice.

item.name: Finca
item.comment: Succinct intersection of mancala-styled rondel movement and set collection. Rock solid euro mechanics with surprising depth from such an ultralight rules overhead.

item.name: Fireball Island: The Curse of Vul-Kar
item.comment: It's some nice dumb 3D fun, with some euro-y design elements that attempt to give the marble flicking a little more game. Pairs excellently with a lot of beer.

item.name: FITS
item.comment:
This is solitaire Tetris (minus the timing, dexterity, and skill) hewn out of horribly wasteful plastic bits.
The one interesting design feature is boards 3 and 4, but the layout of the symbols is fixed, so whatever (small) potential there was for tactical replayability is lost entirely.
This should have been a digital game for both design and ethical reasons. There is a whole world of complex variations and layouts that could have been explored in a digital space with this system, and it wouldn't have ended up in a landfill.
FITS is an uncharacteristic, uninspired blot in Knizia's catalogue. I hope it never comes back into print.

item.name: Five Tribes
item.comment:
Finding clever moves in the sea of meeples is satisfying, and the turn order bidding system plays well to the changing board state.
But it has some troubling undertones with the theming; fakirs (slaves in original version) are bought and sold on the same track as common goods, which feels weird no matter how much people cry "historical accuracy". And a lot of the feminine djinns are depicted as ridiculously busty and revealing, even when they have more inhuman forms; which is an old, tired trope of fantasy art that should have died a long time ago. Save us Naga Vitalist.
I just don't see any reason why the theme and art had to be so off-putting. This is a tile-based abstract game with meeples. The theme could have been anything they wanted.

item.name: Fjords
item.comment:
A simple territory control game split into two strange halves: first you build the map in its entirety, then you find a way to score points on it. The problem for me is that the game is really only played in the first tile-laying half, and Viking placements in the second half are fairly automatic and uninteresting; just following through on moves already made. You can usually determine a winner before a single point has been scored.
Why bifurcate the game like this for seemingly no gain? Why obfuscate an intensely straightforward scoring system with a delayed-feedback mechanism?
I'm also not entirely convinced that bringing in more than 2 players was a good idea in this new edition. Having multiple things hit the board between each of your placements makes the game feel more lively, but also more swingy and even capricious. Lots of unsatisfying moments of Player A winning because Player B didn't stop Player C.
There are faster, more beautiful, more approachable, and more dynamic tile-layers like Taluva and Through the Desert that will maintain my attention over this.

item.name: Flamme Rouge
item.comment:
A clean, fast, retro race without much game.
The differences in card distribution between the two racers makes them feel surprisingly distinct, and the slipstream and exhaustion systems are pretty evocative. But the tuning on those systems is just a little off; slipstreaming feels too strong and exhaustion doesn't feel like enough of a punishment, so the race can end up being excruciatingly close without anyone trying all that hard. It just doesn't significantly respond to creative card play.
I do wish that the turns in the track had a mechanical effect on the race so that changing the track layout would do more than just look cool. That was a missed opportunity.
Flamme Rouge also edges uncomfortably close to being overpriced for what it is. I was lucky enough to get a used copy for twenty bucks, and I feel like I got good value for my money, but I don't know how happy I would be with the game if I had paid anywhere near MSRP. The extra thick chipboard and two piece minis just don't add enough to the game to warrant the extra cost.

item.name: Flip Ships
item.comment: It's fine and you can find fun in here. Feels a bit like a drinking game. Needs some work with the rulebook; a game this simple shouldn't be [i]this[/i] ambiguous with its play sequence and edge cases.

item.name: Food Chain Magnate
item.comment:
Food Chain Magnate is almost unrivaled in the intensity and thoroughness of its satire, even considering Splotter’s high standard for such things. This is a devilish, biting caricature of 1950’s Americana that is one part infatuation and two parts denunciation. The pitch-perfect monochrome visual design, the horribly tokenized employees, the patently absurd marketing tactics, and the brainless, sheep-like, gluttonous behavior of the consumers all contribute to a repulsively amusing atmosphere that few if any games can match.
The jockeying for demand, supply, price, housing, and new restaurant locations on the board is mean-spirited and wonderfully spatial, and it is all deeply integrated with the tempo-oriented employee tableaus. The ebb and flow between these systems is tuned just right, and the rules overhead is surprisingly light for a Splotter.
But lurking under it all are the milestones. To me, they almost irreparably distort what is an otherwise striking example of Splotter's timeless, focused, elegant design philosophy; they feel uncharacteristically scripted, unimaginative, and tacked-on.
I understand their purpose is to provide a source of asymmetry between the players in an otherwise no-luck game, but funnily enough the fastest path to some early milestones is so obvious that they actually have the exact [i]opposite[/i] effect; instead of creating interesting asymmetries, they corral players into pre-planned, predictable lines of play (Train 1 Turn 2 or Hire 3 Turn 3) that dominate the strategic discourse around FCM.
That isn't to say that milestone-like effects don't work in principle. FCM's closest relative, The Great Zimbabwe, has similar first-come-first-served abilities in its Gods and Specialists, but they come at a static cost of VR, the dynamic cost of game-state information, and (crucially) the benefits they provide are almost always exploitable by the other players because of TGZ's mutualistic economy. The significant and unilateral milestone benefits in FCM (that are gained for simply doing what you were going to do anyway) seem positively draconian by comparison. It isn't enough that someone is already losing because their opponents were simply more efficient with their Recruiting Girls, this player now gets to lose [i]even more[/i] because their opponents will be enjoying permanent (and exclusive) reductions in their salaries.
The whole subsystem is particularly brutal to novices, and the jockeying it creates between experienced players isn't very interesting or varied either. I truly believe that the randomized setup, initial restaurant placement, and emergent differences in players' employee tableaus could have been enough to ensure player asymmetry without needing the milestones, but they're just too integrated into the system for me to seriously suggest omitting them.

item.name: For Sale
item.comment: Detailed, subtle filler that I consistently lose; the interconnected bidding rounds are fascinating. One of the best ways to fill 20 minutes, and a prime example of a "Why didn't I think of this?" design.

item.name: Forbidden Island
item.comment:
A pared down Pandemic, if such a thing was possible. The shrinking board was sort of interesting, but this is [i]still[/i] another lifeless symbol-matching coop from Matt Leacock, with unimaginative special powers and painfully obvious decisions. Maybe I'd appreciate his games more if I regularly played with kids, but I'm not quite at that stage in my life yet, so for now I can only say sorry Mr. Leacock, I just don't get it.
The production on this thing is pretty terrible as well; the metal tin is annoying to store, the trophy miniatures are totally unnecessary, the card stock is thin and flimsy, and the water marker pointer doesn't sit flush on the table when clipped in properly. The biggest sin though, is how blatantly the publisher has plastered their name on every single component that had printable space:
In [b]GAMEWRIGHT Ⓡ[/b] Forbidden Island, you will adventure to the homeland of an ancient civilization and search for buried treasures by working together, using special powers, and gathering [b]GAMEWRIGHT Ⓡ[/b] Treasure Cards. But beware, the island is flooding quickly! As the [b]GAMEWRIGHT Ⓡ[/b] Water Meter rises, players will be forced to draw cards from the dreaded [b]GAMEWRIGHT Ⓡ[/b] Flood Deck, which may see regions of the sacred [b]GAMEWRIGHT Ⓡ[/b] Forbidden Island sink into the abyss forever! A [b]GAMEWRIGHT Ⓡ[/b] game brought to you by [b]GAMEWRIGHT Ⓡ[/b].
I thought we had left this overly-corporate mass market board game stuff in the past.

item.name: Formula D
item.comment: There aren't enough car points in any one category to take any meaningful risks with braking or overshooting or downshifting, so you just make the only sensible choice there is on every turn and hope you roll better than your competitors. It's a shame, because the gear selection mechanic is super rad, it deserved to be in a better game.

item.name: The Fox in the Forest
item.comment: Succinct and rather sweet, and with surprisingly interesting trick-taking decision points with only two players. Might lose its luster quickly.

item.name: Fresh Fish
item.comment:
Note: this rating is for the original ruleset [i]only[/i] ("Fresh Fish Classic" in new edition). Don't bother with the new rules.
Fresh Fish's deductive network building is shatteringly brilliant (after a small but painful learning process). Once the system is internalized, the board becomes a dynamic sea of implicit links, positional posturing, risk management, and tactical counter-play that continues to surprise and excite me.
If Fresh Fish was ever given a tasteful production that matched its system's violent beauty, I might consider it perfect.

item.name: Friday
item.comment: Hopelessly on-rails, devoid of any strategic variability, and filled with non-decisions. This plays itself. Solo-exclusive tabletop games have to hold themselves to a higher standard than this. In what world does this pass the time better than a video game when you’re alone?

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment: A hoot and/or a holler. It's very very ugly, but in a warm sort of way.

item.name: Genoa
item.comment: A charming negotiation game with very little rules overhead, and the capability for some seriously complex play. Needs more plays.

item.name: Ginkgopolis
item.comment: An unintuitive combination of mechanisms that is lovely and strange.

item.name: GIPF
item.comment:
GIPF has its Full-Windsor done up so tight that the veins in its neck are starting to bulge, and the ponderous frown that has taken up residence on its face for the last hour or so is threatening to become a permanent tenant.
Lengthier than its children, more austere than its children, more painfully procedural than any of its children, but as brilliant as the best of them. A worthy, if less immediately exciting, foundation for the series.

item.name: Gloomhaven
item.comment:
I really wanted to love this, but after pushing myself through a full, honest 15 scenarios looking for [i]anything[/i] to keep me on the hook, I just had to accept that the whole experience was pretty miserable.
As has been said by so many others, the setup and teardown is prohibitively time consuming, and even a short session requires so much bookkeeping on the part of the game owner that the widespread description of Gloomhaven being "D&D without a DM" feels disingenuous at best.
Enemy AI manages to be both error--prone [i]and[/i] dumb. You would think that a system opaque enough to spawn a challenging fan-made online quiz would produce more meaningful enemy behavior during combat.
Constant modifier deck shuffling feels like a downgrade to custom dice or a bag of tiles for seemingly no other reason than to give players the illusion of less randomness.
The exhaustion/recovery system is needlessly restrictive, frustrating, and completely unthematic, and it is the only real source of difficulty in the whole game. Hoarding cards during the early portions of a scenario is crucial to ensure your character doesn’t become prematurely exhausted, but this means that most scenarios consist of hours and hours of piddling around with Move 2 / Attack 2 effects until you get to the last room and can actually start have fun playing the cards that make your class compelling. Gloomhaven makes no effort to emphasize the importance of this scenario cadence in the rules, and learning it yourself through several three hour delayed player eliminations early on is a vicious, depressing waste of time.
The plot is paper thin and the writing is shockingly cliché for how original the world seemed from the outside. The campaign is also pretty unresponsive to scenarios being done out of the intended order; random characters that the party hasn't met yet will pop in and out of story segments, only to later be "introduced" to the party after circling back to their branching scenario path.
The treasure looting system and communication limits also breed so much tacit hostility with your "teammates" that I am convinced that Gloomhaven, like so many other coops, only works as a solo game. Considering that, why am I paying over a hundred dollars for a solo dungeon crawler that pales in comparison to even the most middling video games in this genre?

item.name: Glory to Rome
item.comment: A fiery, brash card game with nuanced multi-use card interactions and Chudyk’s usual penchant for the flashy. This and Innovation are beautiful foils to one another, and sit as near-equals at the top of his catalog. Maybe doesn’t [i]quite[/i] live up to it’s almost mythical hype, but what could?

item.name: El Grande
item.comment: El Grande is ultra-refined and tightly integrated in the details of its design (the power card bidding, caballero court management, region scoring), but also willfully and delightfully exuberant in its broader strokes (the Castillo, the dials, the shockingly swingy action cards). It's aggressive, bluffy, well-paced, and just downright [i]fun[/i]. If all the old classic euros got together for a family reunion, El Grande would be the drunken uncle dancing on the banquet table.

item.name: El Grande: König & Intrigant
item.comment:
The deterministic hands of cards counterintuitively creates [i]more[/i] tactical chaos despite a smoothing of the long-term randomness of the action decks, and this becomes especially overbearing when there are potentially [i]five[/i] copies of a destructive action card floating around at the table, instead of one or two. The distribution of the actions seems off as well, being tilted more towards court denial and straight up removal of opponents' pieces rather than caballero movement on the board, which always maintained a satisfying presence in the base game because one fifth of the action cards were variable move powers. This variation has been replaced by a static and unimaginably boring Intrigue card, which never allowed for the subtle caballero management of the base game's intrigue deck.
The fusing of the actions cards with the turn order bid also fails to capture any of the excitement or drama of the draft in the base game, and much of the texture of managing your opponents' positions against the shared pool of actions has been lost. This, more than anything, is what makes this expansion a failure for me: for every interesting decision point K&I introduces, it seems to equally neuter much of El Grande's wit and soul.
This is a radical variant with lofty goals, and I respect what it was trying to accomplish, but if El Grande had shipped like this, as the designer supposedly intended, I would have never taken to it. Sure, this was a crunchy experience on its own terms, but it wasn't the irreverent El Grande I know and love, and unfortunately for K&I, this is a zero-sum game.

item.name: Great Western Trail (Second Edition)
item.comment:
I can't seem to feel anything but lukewarm on GWT after a few plays. Interaction is depressingly minimal, even for a heavy modern euro, and the strategic paths seem fairly isolated and lacking in meaningful intersection. There's also a distinct lack of drama in this; turns are so incremental and the whole process so procedural that I never felt clever or sneaky or bold, just vaguely busy.
If I'm going to dedicate 2-3 hours to a solitaire optimization game I'd rather have A Feast for Odin for its system's rich interdependencies or Underwater Cities for its consistent dopamine dispensing.

item.name: The Great Zimbabwe
item.comment:
About as unified and tightly refined as a board game can be; everything is [i]just[/i] so. The Great Zimbabwe is a dynamic and deeply mutualistic race of game-state manipulation and tempo management that condenses an absurd number of meaningful decisions into 75 minutes .
Lush, inventive, and teeming with understated genius like VR costs and the Generosity of Kings turn order bid. This is Splotter at their absolute best.

item.name: The Grizzled
item.comment: While unabashedly earnest in its attempt at paying respect to the victims of World War I, the simplistic symbol-matching gameplay feels like it works against the seriousness of its subject matter, and the whole package ends up feeling strangely tone-deaf.

item.name: Gulf, Mobile & Ohio
item.comment: Feels entirely distinct from the other Winsome cube rails. The intense emphasis on timing and tactics and point-conversion make this feel strangely and pleasantly euro-like, and with such a snappy playtime I can see myself returning to this often.

item.name: Hadara
item.comment: I didn't think it was possible to make the 7 Wonders formula [i]less [/i] interesting. Track-nudging, set collection, and point conversion so lifeless and disenchanting as to almost feel like a satire of modern euro design.

item.name: Hamsterrolle
item.comment:
There is room for some [i]very[/i] clever play in here once players become more aggressive and abuse the wheel's rotation for destabilizing pieces. Entirely unique and entirely wonderful.
House rule: no touching the wheel with your body while placing pieces.

item.name: Hannibal: Rome vs. Carthage
item.comment:
It's a tragic thing, really. Hannibal is a fascinating and variable game of card-driven area control and strategic attrition that is very nearly ruined by an out-of-place and shockingly simplistic go-fish battle card system.
I've tried to see the depth that many of the battle system's fans purport it to have, but after half a dozen plays I've never once seen that depth realized in actual play. Just memorize the deck distribution, count your cards, and play what you have the most of. Whoever was dealt the better hand and rolled well enough to counterattack will win, tactics be damned, and almost no decisions will have been made during the whole laborious process. This weird mini-game inflates Hannibal's already long playtime for little gain, both in its procedure and its physical bookkeeping (make sure to shuffle up that combat deck thoroughly for the three hundredth time!)
I just fail to see what this subsystem accomplishes that another, faster combat resolution system couldn't have (dice etc). It's a shame, because the overarching board play with the strategy cards, army movement, and political control is genuinely great and tense, it deserved better.

item.name: Hansa Teutonica
item.comment: An exemplary euro design. This is elegant, balanced between strategy and tactics, and is filled with constant player interaction of a particularly parasitic sort. Hansa Teutonica has now stood up to over a dozen thoughtful plays, and my respect and admiration for the design seems to continually deepen. I can consider this nothing less than a personal classic at this point.

item.name: Le Havre
item.comment:
A Rosenburg game of thin margins and stuttering efficiency swings. The supply chain was as complex as I was led to believe, but Le Havre’s status as a sleek logistics game seem overstated; despite its differences in tempo it felt more like any of Rosenburg's other heavy resource/point conversion games than I was expecting. Throw it on the pile I suppose.
Le Havre also felt far too long for what it was, but that may have been because we played with four inexperienced players. I’ll return to this again, but I felt surprisingly lukewarm after a first play.

item.name: Heroes of Land, Air & Sea
item.comment:
On the verge of being really fun. Everything is tuned just a hair too complicated for a game that is meant to be kind of ridiculous: the sheer number of interacting statistics on the player boards and tactics cards and troop ability cards make combat opaque and prohibitively error-prone, rather than frequent and aggressive and decisive like the game intended.
Maybe with enough frequent plays the cumulative effect of all these modifiers becomes easier to parse, but I personally don't want a big, stompy, raucous game like this demanding that kind of extended, focused attention to get the most out of it.

item.name: High Frontier 4 All
item.comment:
This one is heartbreaking. I want to love it so, so bad. The raw [i]passion[/i] for the physics of space travel that HF exudes and the overwhelming expanse of the full solar system board are intoxicating, but in actual play HF ended up being a dreary, draining experience that doesn't properly communicate the grandeur of its subject matter.
My main issue with High Frontier is that its science and its thematic touches will only be cool to people that are [i]already[/i] into space; as a learning tool it's almost worthless. Its faithful simulation of the finer points of space travel (flybys, the rocket equation, Lagrange points, the Oberth effect) is pretty unbelievable for a board game, but if a player doesn't already have an intuitive understanding of these topics the game will seem like a nonsensical, arbitrary collection of number-crunching rules. I don't think anyone that hasn't seen an animation of a Hohmann transfer is going to gain any insight into the maneuver by zigzagging along HF's orbit lines.
Even when the movement system is internalized and the subtleties of each astronomical body is understood, the actual pick-up-and-deliver core of the game ends up feeling flat and weirdly unpredictable. The failure die is just such a bizarre and ham-fisted inclusion when HF is attempting to realistically simulate a human endeavor that is infamous for its regulatory prudence.
Maybe I would be easier on High Frontier if Kerbal Space Program didn't exist, with its almost limitless creative freedom and its pedagogical exuberance. And it also benefits immensely from the video format: efforts in mission planning and execution are generously rewarded with vivid, breathtaking visual feedback (rather than the slight nudge of a plastic rocket pawn).

item.name: High Society
item.comment: The artwork of the newest edition is gorgeous and refreshingly inclusive, but the bidding is a little flat and the game length uncertainty can be a little too swingy. It’s not a bad filler though, and I respect it’s (unsurprising) mechanical completeness, especially the reverse auctions.

item.name: Hive
item.comment: Enormous strategic depth, beautiful weighty tiles. It's great, but occasionally a little static.

item.name: Hive: The Ladybug
item.comment: Another short range skirmisher, like the spiders, but with a bit more flexibility. Doesn't seemed to have a huge impact on most games, but she's nice to have around.

item.name: Hive: The Mosquito
item.comment: A creative new addition to Hive. It's usually just a fourth ant, but there are a huge number of strong, creative moves to be made.

item.name: Hive: The Pillbug
item.comment:
After trying and trying to get this piece to work, I've accepted that I just don't like what the Pillbug does to the game. Games warp [i]heavily[/i] around the positioning of this one piece, which feels imbalanced and a little inelegant, and the Pillbug comes with more rules overhead than every piece in the base game combined. It also lengthens the playtime of Hive well beyond what I consider reasonable.
While it does open up some interesting moves and defensive positions, I don't think it's worth the overhead and shift in focus. I think it's telling that Hive Pocket and Carbon still omit this.

item.name: Hues and Cues
item.comment: What word properly conveys the difference between rgb(247, 78, 57) and rgb(240, 84, 53)? You don't know and neither do the people guessing. Have fun!

item.name: I should have known that!
item.comment: Received as a gift. It was fuel for a road trip, but the scoring system was inconsistent and lazy, and some of the trivia was straight up false. Bleh.

item.name: Imperial
item.comment:
Thorny, tempo-oriented intersection of area control and investment. Feels somewhat like a train game, but with a considerably shorter playtime and more emphasis on emergent narrative and drama (things I value quite highly because I am a fool).
Add this to the now quite long list of games that make me hesitant to ever sit down for another game of 18xx.

item.name: Indonesia
item.comment:
This is a sobering reminder of all the great, singular designs that may have been lost to the maw of 18xx. Here is a game that clearly borrowed heavily from the framework, but is so adventurous and self-assured as to stand firmly in its own category.
The merger system gives Indonesia a dynamism that I have found in few other economic games; companies change hands constantly as mergers are resolved for equally offensive and defensive reasons, and player positions become delightfully fluid.
The parasitic, catch-22 relationship between producers and shippers is fascinating, and never seems to play out exactly the same way twice. I’m a little sad I haven’t seen more of this asymmetric interdependency in other economic games.
I will admit that out of the box, Indonesia is (while undeniably beautiful) completely unusable as a game object. The map is two sizes too small, the wooden pieces and cardboard ships are two sizes too big, and tracking city demand with a pile of chits is untenable. Most of the components need straight up replacing, and that's a big ask for a game this expensive.

item.name: Inis
item.comment: I recently returned to this and had a pretty disappointing experience that didn't live up to my fond memory. I'm beginning to worry that Inis may have some fundamental issues, but there is so much potential for a great game in here that I'm going to give it its due and play it a few more times before settling on an updated score. It'll rest here for now.

item.name: Innovation
item.comment:
Endlessly variable and wonderfully bombastic card game that is a potent breath of fresh air amongst the hordes of games with ten times the elegance but one tenth the soul. Every game will see someone declaring that a particular card is broken beyond reason, only for that same card to be completely unnoteworthy in the next game, and another card taking its place as the bane of the table.
I've never played the same game of Innovation twice, and I doubt I ever will. Like Magic, sometimes it's a blowout and you have a bit of a non-game, but it's over in 25 minutes, you laugh, shuffle up, and go again. Electrifying in the moment, striking in the aggregate; this might be the most game you can get for fifteen bucks.

item.name: Irish Gauge
item.comment:
Beautiful, slim cube rail with a thorny, probabilistic dividend payout system. There are thankfully enough tools given to the players to influence the game length and the timing and distribution of dividends to ensure the variance doesn't feel oppressive or overtly unfair. This is randomness done right.
Irish Gauge gets right to the essence of the shared incentive decision space with even less rules overhead than Chicago Express, and would be my first choice for introducing cube rails to non-economic gamers.

item.name: Iwari
item.comment:
Bristling, distilled area majority that is astonishing in its simultaneous simplicity and inventiveness.
The game system has been around for more than twenty years, but Iwari wraps it up in a beautiful and accessible production that finally does the mechanisms justice on the shelf and on the table. Instant evergreen.

item.name: Jaipur
item.comment: A clever set collection / hand management game that responds well to thoughtful play. Good clean filler for two, but perhaps a little drama-less.

item.name: Just One
item.comment:
That’s it? A party game with almost no party in it. It doesn’t have the laughs of Celebrities, the insightful discussions of Wavelength, or the mechanical interest of Decrypto.
The main selling point (duplicate clues being eliminated) felt like a rare event, even at higher player counts, and I’ve only seen it affect the outcome of a guess a handful of times. Scoring 10+ doesn’t feel like much of a challenge.
I’m not sure why this is so highly regarded.

item.name: Keyflower
item.comment: Solid blending of euro mechanisms that seem at first blush to be contradictory, but reveal themselves to be tightly integrated. Navigating the web of bidding, worker placement, logistics, and actually finding a way to score points with your lonely little pool of workers is an exercise in being pulled in ten different directions at once (in a good way). I’m not sure if this completely rises above its point-salad trappings, but Keyflower is a cut above its cousins.

item.name: The King Is Dead: Second Edition
item.comment: Raw, knife-edge area majority that is often decided by delicate (but meaningful) tie-breakers. Does so much with so little.

item.name: King of Tokyo
item.comment: The theme is fun, and the art is fun, and chucking dice is fun, but somehow all of these things added together makes for a pretty middling game. Most players in my group preferred combat (fun) to going for points (boring), but without a player going the boring route, the game stretches on too long.
