Eliminated players are also never that invested in watching the rest of the game play out, which is always a deal breaker for any game with player elimination.

item.name: Kingdom Builder
item.comment: Lean, crunchy snack. Needs at least four to be interesting, but with four it also becomes a bit long for what it is.

item.name: KLASK
item.comment: This rules. The biscuits were a stroke of genius and keep KLASK from feeling stale or derivative: this could only be a magnetic game. Maybe it's a gimmick, but it's a fun one.

item.name: L.L.A.M.A.
item.comment: Knizia's...Uno? A brutally high variance card game with few decisions.

item.name: LCR
item.comment: Meaningless gambling, and I like gambling.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings
item.comment: A hard game to rate. It was a challenging and interesting puzzle to solve, and I appreciate a Lord of the Rings game having a more focused, character-driven scope. But I feel that Knizia's iron grip of elegance and simplicity may have squeezed some of the life out of Tolkien's world. With just a few more allowances given to more expressive mechanical design this system could have captured the fellowship's story beautifully, but as it is the whole quest feels too static and the characters feel too lifeless.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation
item.comment: All the best parts of Knizian design (elegant ruleset, hidden depth, breezy pacing) presented with unexpected thematic expressiveness. This is a bluffy and tense engagement that usually lasts less than a half hour. One of Knizia's very best two-player designs, it's a shame this isn't in print anymore.

item.name: Lost Cities
item.comment: A tiny bit of tension and even less meaningful interaction. Lost Cities is severely lacking in the intensity of so many other excellent quick games for two (many by Knizia himself). Particularly Battle Line, which asks similar questions in a similar playtime but with far more cleverness and depth.

item.name: LUNA Capital
item.comment:
Fairly insipid lot-taking euro. The spatial restrictions within your colony never felt that constraining or impactful, and so creating good groups of buildings felt more like raw set-collection rather than a result of creative tile placement, which is disappointing.
This also desperately needed a scoring reference for each player in the box; with ten categories of points coming from ten different building types a game can be easily lost by simply forgetting a point category.

item.name: Magic: The Gathering
item.comment:
What am I supposed to do? The sheer [i]totality[/i] of Magic almost puts it beyond normal hobby game classification. Can this even meaningfully be compared to one-box board games or small-run LCG's/CCG's? I'm not sure. Rating this at all feels wrong somehow, so I am hereby giving an official grain of salt warning: my perfect score here does appropriately express my infatuation with the design, but I feel that Magic is simply beyond the scope of BGG, and so any rating I assign to it should be disregarded for the purposes of comparing my rated games. Having said that:
This game utterly consumed a good portion of my adolescence. Magic was single-handedly responsible for making many of my friendships in school, friendships I still have! If I had to name the game that has had the most substantial impact on my day-to-day life, it's Magic hands down.
The design itself is strikingly simple, and seems designed from the ground up to strongly evoke distinct mechanical personalities through its color pie, personalities that are often delightfully mirrored in players. Few games can rival Magic's simultaneous gentle learning curve and staggering, overwhelming nuance. With some clean vanilla decks, a lifetime obsession can be introduced in only fifteen minutes.
The moment-to-moment card game of Magic is perhaps best preserved in limited play; sealed and draft events offer an exhilarating distillation of nearly simultaneous deck construction and play. However it is the relaxed eternal formats like Commander that allowed Magic to become a deeply personal and valuable vessel for self-expression in my group. With decades of design to pick through, our little kitchen table micro-meta has had all its player personalities vividly codified in deck construction in ways we hadn't seen in standard play. Our decks, with all their pet cards and bitter reactionary inclusions and exuberant jank have become nothing short of hallowed ground.
I might not be as ruthlessly dedicated as I once was, but I return to Magic often, and even when I'm not actively playing games I find myself spending too many sleepless nights tinkering in the card database. I expect to fall in and out of love with Magic for the rest of my life.

item.name: Mao
item.comment:
The anti-game. I'm convinced that Mao serves no other purpose than to give cliquey, vain, hyper-competitive children the opportunity to exchange snickering glances with each other over how cleverly they're alienating and berating everyone who's not "in on it".
What's that? I just hate Mao because [i]I[/i] was the quiet kid that didn't get the game and couldn't handle being made fun of? I don't see how that's relevant.
Play some Zendo.

item.name: Mariposas
item.comment:
I was hopeful going into Mariposas because of the shared board, which usually implies some sort of interaction or spatial jockeying between players, but sadly there was none to be found. You play your own little set-collection racing puzzle with almost no regard at all for your opponents. Even just a single rudimentary blocking rule (ala El Dorado) could have helped Mariposas [i]immensely[/i], and I'm not sure it would have made it too mean for a family game.
Mariposas also relies heavily on randomized pools (action cards, goals, city tiles) that create restrictions that often feel arbitrary and make each round obsessively tactical. The iconography on the goals is also a little hard to parse, and interpreting above/below/left/right on a hex board goes a little beyond a family game's mental overhead in my opinion.
The theme is done reasonably well and feels unique, and the generational leapfrogging is compelling, but these elements are lost in all the tepidness.
I feel bad for not taking to Hargrave's designs; she is such a wonderful ray of hope for the success of women in the medium, and I hope she has a long future in the industry. I just don't care for her games.

item.name: Martian Chess
item.comment:
Shatters standard preconceptions. The first three plays felt downright magical as I came to grips with Martian Chess's slippery definition of "my piece" and "your piece". Martian Chess seems explicitly crafted to subvert every instinct cultivated by chess-like games, and there is something wonderful about feeling so utterly hopeless in such a familiar game-space.
Once the cause and effect of the system is internalized though, the game seems to devolve rather quickly into stalemates and unwinnable positions. This is an amazing exercise in expanding your mind, but so far it hasn't stood up to extended play. Absolutely worth trying, but just for a bit.

item.name: Mastermind
item.comment: There is some creative logic required to solve the puzzle, but the player designated as the mastermind has no agency at all in the physical game, so this is only good as a single player computer-controlled puzzle. Zendo has a similar player role of "master", but allows that player enormous creative freedom in their construction of counter-examples.

item.name: Medici
item.comment:
This was already underwhelming in a vacuum, but after finally getting Ra to the table and seeing what Knizia managed to achieve with the once-around lot-creation format, I'm happy to let Medici rot in the annals of history.
Sure, this might be the more "elegant" of the two, but it lacks the excitement and the theatrics of Ra and is even more susceptible to overwhelming luck of the draw . Playing up to 6 doesn't earn you a pardon, Medici, good riddance.

item.name: Medina (Second Edition)
item.comment:
It looks stunning and has some compelling elements of brinkmanship and sabotage with constructing palaces, but opportunities to score are usually never created actively by a player, but only [i]given[/i] to them by the collective actions of their opponents. While that sounds fascinating on paper, it really just means that your own turn is spent agonizing between often equally bad options and searching for ways to do as little as possible with your two pieces per turn; it's exhausting, never liberating or rewarding.
Medina also heavily rewards the player who is last to move in most situations (like with the frustrating tit-for-tat tower tiles), so many conflicts devolve into a stale war of attrition, including against your own supply of pieces. The game even entices players to collect a resource which lets them [i]abstain from playing the game[/i]! The game seems to admit that many times, the best move is no move at all, and while that isn't a broken strategic space by any means, and I recognize it's depth, I feel sort of bothered by it.

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment: Rating after six scenarios. Streamlined and fast. Gives a satisfying skirmish experience in usually an hour or less. Rating may fluctuate as I play more scenarios and experiment with expansions.

item.name: Mexican Train
item.comment: Another one of those high variance, zero-thought “activity games” that is often played at family reunions. Maybe one day extended families can bond over a game that has decisions in it!

item.name: The Mind
item.comment:
Cool concept, and so fun to see everyone finally get it. It's a worthwhile novelty, but anyone who has played improv games with similar structures (embarrassingly, me) might not be as blown away by it.
I do wish that the rules were less ambiguous as to what constitutes "coordination" and "secret signals". As I originally read it, I thought that all players had to remain silent and not make any facial expressions at all. I believed that this reading was supported by the repeated emphasis placed on timing, and nothing else, in the rules. The community disagrees, and I will admit that the Mind is a better game for it.
These types of games [i]need[/i] to be more explicit with their communication limits. It's absolutely no fun to argue with other players at the table about what communication is allowed based off of nothing but personal interpretation of the "spirit" of the rules. Playtest, find the best communication limits, then give detailed, clear, specific examples in your rulebook of what is and isn't allowed. Don't put the onus to police on your players.

item.name: Modern Art
item.comment:
Auctions, distilled. Having multiple auction formats in the same game is revelatory, and the respective tendencies of these formats to warp bidding patterns and influence player psychology is wonderfully prone to abuse. The delicate hand management and player-driven economy are equally powerful elements of the design; it’s amazing it all stems from a rule set that is a few paragraphs long at most, though I suppose with Knizia that isn't too surprising.
This is an absolute evergreen, and adds enormous value to a collection, especially when its unexpected and delightful predisposition towards satire and roleplay make it so engaging to non-economic gamers who would normally be bored to tears by "better" closed-economy auction games like the Estates or Container.

item.name: Mottainai
item.comment:
Not a terrible attempt at streamlining Glory to Rome for lower player counts, but I feel something may have been lost in the process. The clean, sanded edges don’t quite have the same spunk.
The split tableau that Mottainai added also strangely makes it [i]harder[/i] to teach than it’s predecessor, despite being a smaller, faster game.
I’m glad this exists so more people can get a taste of this system, but I also hate that this exists because it reminds me of the future GtR could have had. [i]Sigh.[/i]

item.name: Mr Lister's Quiz Shootout
item.comment: Another game-less collection of trivia cards. The questions are occasionally too vague and the data often conflicts with cursory google searches (a distressingly common trend in these types of games). The set-collection-based scoring is a thoroughly useless complication in the rules; it does nothing but unnecessarily lengthen the game and often makes players less enthusiastic about winning a round for a drink they already have. It should have been first to any five cards wins.

item.name: My City
item.comment:
Hey It's FITS Legacy! Instead of following in its parent's footsteps by being a terrible game made out of chunky plastic bits that will end up in a landfill, My City decided it was just gonna be a kinda okay game made out of plastic-varnished chipboard that will [i]also[/i] end up in a landfill.
As a legacy experience, My City is deeply underwhelming. The enclosed chapters offer little more than slight scoring changes or mild spatial restrictions on the board, and even new tiles don't ever give the campaign any serious sense of progress or reinvention. The compensation stickers given out to players at the end of each chapter don't make anyone's board feel all that unique, and the cumulative campaign scoring was a pretty pointless "goal" to strive for, especially as the relative distances between players grew.
I just don't understand how the legacy genre has seemingly learned [i]nothing[/i] from decades of excellent single-player puzzle video game design. There are so many digital games that have shown the power and beauty of guiding a player through every possible permutation of a mechanism with intent, often leading to unexpected, mind-shattering subversion (Braid, the Witness, Baba is You, Opus Magnum). Having such a huge catalog of inspiration, why (why!) are legacy board games so afraid to push the boundaries of their systems?
Why should I be impressed by a new building tile that can score a few more points or a new rock sticker or a slightly different start location on my player board? These are not interesting developments, they do not make me see the system in a new light or reveal previously unseen subtleties! It's just [i]fluff[/i], and it is made all the worse by the nature of the medium: this is made of physical stuff, designed to be thrown out after a playthrough. If you are going to make the creative (and ethical) decision to render your one-play game out of tree parts, you had better have a good reason. My City doesn't have one.

item.name: Neuland
item.comment:
While this presented a fascinating distillation of Roads & Boats style logistics, with an increased emphasis on lock-outs and blocking, after a half dozen plays I'm feeling like I've seen all of Neuland's tricks. This is very much an "aha" game that wears out its welcome quickly once its admittedly inventive details have been understood: resources abstracted away to worker movement; variable action costs relating to distances on the board; the emergent potential of double-turns; the ability to choke out access to complex resources by blocking the supply chain "upstream"; and working through the supply chain efficiently over many turns by managing worker lay-down timing. It's all very, [i]very[/i] clever, but I fear only to a point.
I'm beginning to appreciate just how much the maximalist excess of Roads & Boats contributes to its allure.

item.name: Neuroshima Hex! 3.0
item.comment:
I was initially excited by the spatial and sequential combat puzzle, but the random tile drawing system felt like a completely unnecessary injection of high-variance luck into a nice crunchy battle system. Why not let each player select from a limited supply of units and one-time effects at will? Or at least have a rotating hand of 5-7 tiles? I just don't see what is gained from such a restrictive system.
This might need more plays.

item.name: No Thanks!
item.comment: Good filler that is really a push-your-luck game at heart. Might be a little too mathy for a such a lighthearted game, but it's accessible and doesn't overstay its welcome.

item.name: Noria
item.comment:
Clever, crunchy modern euro. Noria's "wheelbuilding" could have so easily felt gimmicky, but the deterministic rotations give the system a clear sense of look-ahead that rewards strategic positioning of discs. The wheel perhaps becomes too forgiving when considering the additional rotation and swap actions though: near the end of the game when players are flush with knowledge tokens, the wheel seems to scarcely matter anymore, and that's a bit of a shame. I honestly would have preferred these options to be omitted entirely, or at least made prohibitively expensive.
I really enjoy the politician manipulation. It offers some impressively gritty player interaction and the competitive balance of locking in your own scoring opportunities while kneecapping your opponents' is tense. The hugely valuable potential of a fully developed track incentivizes specialization, while the uncertainty of each track's maximum potential value incentivizes versatility. The dilemma works well.
These features are inventive, but Noria doesn't entirely escape its modern euro roots; this is still a resource converting engine builder under all the wheels and score matrix shenanigans. I'm not sure I'll be discovering anything new from Noria on a dozenth play, but for now I'm fond of it.
I will say that it is [i]truly[/i] uplifting to have a game like this designed by a woman; the world of board game design is already uncomfortably dominated by men, and this is doubly true for heavy euros.

item.name: Oceans
item.comment:
A slightly more forgiving but perhaps slightly more interesting Evolution: Climate.
I do really enjoy the expanded adjacency mechanics in Oceans, it puts more direct focus on your opponent's tableaus rather than on a limited resource pool, but the resiliency of the species against extinction has removed some of the potency that was found in E:C.
The box is gorgeous but I don't actually care for the look of the components themselves, the fish tokens and trays are a little garish and don't really reflect the watercolor aesthetic of the box, and they feel overproduced for what is essentially a two-deck card game. Oceans probably should have been half the size and half the price.

item.name: Onitama
item.comment: With so many fantastic abstracts out there this just feels hollow. It’s not bad, it just suffers in the shadow of greater games.

item.name: Oraklos
item.comment:
A real-time pattern recognition game that strangely assigns different patterns to each player for the round, resulting in some players becoming arbitrarily hosed or even outright eliminated depending on the layout of the cubes. The ability to "seed" the distribution after seeing your needed colors is a nice touch in mitigating this, but the rules on forming valid sequences are so stringent that it rarely seems to help; someone is gonna get shafted.
I would never, ever play this over Ricochet Robots, with its intense and wonderfully frantic sense of communal struggle against a [i]shared[/i] problem (that is mathematically guaranteed to be solvable). This not only makes RR a more directly competitive and social experience, but allows everyone to fully recognize the cleverness of the best solution offered, something sorely lacking from the heads-down searching of Oraklos.

item.name: Orléans
item.comment: Some people have clearly found something to love in here, and I can't see it: it was all just so [i]intensely[/i] dull. It's almost offensive in how utterly committed it is to being inoffensive.

item.name: Pampas Railroads
item.comment:
Feels particularly sluggish and antiquated in the shadow of its descendent Wabash Cannonball / Chicago Express, which offers just as much game in one third the time. There was also a surprisingly intense snowball effect that is usually (and thankfully) absent from Bohrer's other designs, which only made Pampas's length even more painful as differences in player positions became insurmountable. There just isn't enough flexibility in the Winsome cube-rails system to sustain a game of this length.
Side note: the income tracker included with the first edition uses an insane base-10 token system that makes it laughably unreadable at a glance. It is the worst game component I've ever seen, and it is very dear to my heart for that reason.

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: Maybe I came to this game too late, but I was expecting a lot more. It was just a color matching puzzle. My experience with it is probably influenced by other co-op titles that built off of Pandemic's success, but I was shocked at how simple and thematically disconnected the main mechanisms felt.

item.name: Patchwork
item.comment:
After a few dozen plays Patchwork reveals itself to be an unusually tactical and stressful zero-sum tempo game, rather than the more laidback polyomino puzzler I thought it was. Optimizing the leapfrogging action economy / button supply is really where the game is played, not in laying tiles well.
The cleanliness of the design is remarkable, but a game of Patchwork takes on a stuttering flow that feels strangely exhausting for such a light game.

item.name: Photosynthesis
item.comment: A little dull. Board felt way too crowded at four players, and the interesting tactical potential of the shadow mechanic didn't feel realized in the actual gameplay. I'll try it again at two or three players.

item.name: Pictures
item.comment: Unique party game that brought me back to my Cranium days. Maybe it’ll wear out its welcome on a revisit, but I can’t deny the fun I had on a first spin. This one goes in the “please, please stay good” bin.

item.name: Piratenbillard
item.comment: Surprisingly receptive to skilled play, especially given how chaotic and uncontrollable it seemed at first blush. [i]Vastly[/i] improved by Frank Branham's scoring variant which is circulated here, which lets Piratenbillard realize its full potential as an exciting, aggressive dexterity game up there with the best in the genre. It's a real shame this was lost to obscurity.

item.name: Planet Steam
item.comment:
I [i]love[/i] the modular minis (probably more than I should), but the game seems to be a pretty drab economic resource shuffler with too many time-consuming auctions and too little excitement.
I'm not convinced that the goods market really works as intended. Price fluctuations were [i]horribly[/i] sluggish; as a friend of mine put it, the state of the market seems to be reacting to what players did two rounds ago. Maybe that enables some clever speculation with advanced players, but for me the latency was overwhelming and made the whole thing pretty unresponsive to tactical play. The market also seems to break a little when goods bottom out to 0 and it takes forever for the prices to rise enough to incentivize anyone to make a sale, especially when there isn't a ton of time left in the game. I don't know, something just feels off about the whole system, and I don't have much desire to return to Planet Steam and find out if that was just due to inexperience.

item.name: Poker
item.comment:
A horrible, wonderful game. Must be played for real money; enough to care about losing.
Hold'em is the obvious favorite (for a whippersnapper like me), but there is enormous joy in the other variants minus any form of draw poker. HORSE games are something else.
There is admittedly a [i]lot[/i] of downtime if you're playing competently, but with the right environment that's hopefully mitigated.

item.name: Polynesia
item.comment: A game whose tight focus feels limiting rather than elegant. There seem to be too few point sources for what is often an eight or nine round game, so disparate levels of play can result in frustratingly similar scores. The two-currency system also feels a little wonky; the decision of which resource to use for a route often feels incidental. The requirement of needing an “escort” to use another player’s route also usually just ends up getting in the way of the potential parasitism. A miss from Sylvester that feels strangely underdeveloped.

item.name: Ponzi Scheme
item.comment: Raucous game of hot potato that doesn’t outstay its welcome. It’s delightful to explore a game space that is meticulously designed to be so fundamentally broken. This brings out brashness almost immediately as everyone scrambles to not be the one left holding the bag under the hopeless inevitability of it all collapsing.

item.name: Port Royal
item.comment: Paper thin, meaningless little card game. I'm shocked at how boring this was, as I consider push-your-luck as a mechanic to be almost intrinsically exciting no matter the context; it's an achievement to have made it this joyless.

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment:
Reminds me heavily of Age of Steam in that the primary obstacles that players will be wrestling with are prudent budgetary planning and economic risk management. The route building is a little less interesting here though, and the same is true of the auctions (which have a tendency to swing wildly in value based on unpredictable deck ordering or player liquidity).
Power Grid's win condition (in combination with its turn order system) also creates a strange hyper-fixation in players on setting up for a big last-round tempo burst across the finish line, which is a game cadence that I find personally unsatisfying; it feels a little sad to me that consistent, sound business decisions in the early and mid game of Power Grid seems largely overshadowed by this back-loaded brinksmanship.

item.name: Project L
item.comment: Lavish little polyomino puzzler with cheeky engine-building tendencies. Scores seem to be very tight with good play, so I do worry that the game may become stale and overly reliant on unsatisfying micro-optimizations as players approach the skill ceiling.

item.name: Pueblo
item.comment: Finally, a board game with meaningful 3D elements that is actually good! It's fast, mean, mentally demanding, and totally unlike anything else I've ever played. I'm very excited to get my hands on the new edition and experiment with the "gardens" variant, I suspect that I may enjoy a smaller board that forces building upwards more quickly.

item.name: Pulsar 2849
item.comment: Mild, lightly pleasing modern euro. The median values during dice drafting affecting a permanent turn order track was Pulsar’s most compelling subsystem, and I enjoyed the integration of a shared map. It’s still a lot of bland goal-based scoring and engine building effects under the hood, but I could see myself turning to this again when I fancy that type of experience.

item.name: PÜNCT
item.comment: Contemplative and subtle; contains deep insights into the use of three-dimensional topology as a defensive game device. I have played this the least out of the series, and thus have a softer stance on it, but I always find myself coming away satisfied and properly mind-melted after my games. I expect this score to go up.

item.name: The Quacks of Quedlinburg
item.comment: Fun, thoughtless token puller that understands what makes push-your-luck exciting, but is a bit too dominated by good luck rather than good play for my tastes. That isn't helped by the laughable pittance of a catch-up mechanism that does so little to help a player that has had a truly terrible round.

item.name: Quantum
item.comment:
Sleek and aggressive, with an obscenely clever dice system where movement, combat strength, cube construction ability, and special actions are all tied up into a single pip value. Chaining ship moves and abilities together on a turn is exciting, and the luck of the dice is used to great effect with ship reorganization and never feels overbearing during combat. The advancement cards also add a nice peppering of flavorful asymmetry that keeps Quantum from feeling too abstract.
However, Quantum has a pretty intense "rich get richer" effect that is hard to ignore, with ongoing ability cards being given out for doing the stuff that helps you win anyway. Fans will say that this is justified by Quantum having such a short playtime, but I think that might be overstated. This is solidly an hour-long game (especially with larger maps and more cubes per player), and that isn't [i]quite[/i] short enough to take the sting out of an early tempo loss putting you on the back foot for the whole game.

item.name: The Quest for El Dorado
item.comment: Tense, fast, exciting, and dead simple. Good stuff.

item.name: Ra
item.comment: I unequivocally blow chunks at this, but Ra is a wonderful bidding game that is absolutely filled to the brim with charisma and sass under all the mundane scoring matrices and set collection. There's a little luck in here to be sure, but with a 45 minute playtime, a satisfying number of interesting decisions, and a heaping serving of melodrama, I can think of few other auction games I'd rather play, if for no other reason than to yell "RA!" at people.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment:
Fast, clean, and still fun after 600+ online plays. RFTG sets a remarkable standard for card-based tableau builders.
The deck is expertly constructed with only a few dud cards, engine building is sophisticated and diverse, and the phase selection system consistently rewards thoughtful analysis of your opponents' positions.
My only problem with the system is the 6-cost developments. They frustratingly obfuscate the true score during the course of play, and their scripted, specific point conversions put a damper on the wonderful emergent properties of RFTG. I wish they could all have been more like Research Labs, with more opaque and versatile synergies and use-cases, instead of literally doling out points for having specific cards ([i]by name[/i]) in your tableau.
Also, the art sucks. I'm so, [i]so[/i] tired of having to put up with bad art in otherwise excellent card games. I could easily see myself giving RFTG another point if it was nice to look at.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy: The Gathering Storm
item.comment:
18 wonderful cards hidden in a box of bloat.
The solitaire mode is okay, but there are free, widely available digital implementations of RFTG with challenging AI opponents if you want to play alone, and the custom cards and additional player are strange additions that I don't think anyone asked for.
The main mechanical draw, the goal tiles, can occasionally provide some interesting tug-of-war tension between players with similar tableaus, but for me they unforgivably dilute the nothing-but-cards elegance of the design and hinders its dynamism. The base game encourages you to pay some attention to your opponents to get a read on their incentives and make clever plays with your phase selection, but with the goals included this rewarding "gut-check" interaction instead becomes a repetitive exercise of counting your opponent's blue and brown worlds or counting their developments or counting their unique phase abilities or counting their cards in hand or counting their VP chips, all in effort to just throw a couple more unimaginative points on your score pile.
I might be willing to forgive the tediousness if the goals felt unique from game to game, but with such a tiny pool of tiles to choose from they feel samey almost immediately. Similarly if the goals had managed to drastically change the evaluation of your cards in hand they may have been worthwhile, but their effects are so bland that they mostly reward you for playing the cards you were going to play anyway. I understand the goals are meant to fill in some of the gaps in the deck, but that balance should have been provided by adding or changing cards, full stop.
The new cards and start worlds are genuinely fantastic. Really they are. I just wish they had come in a mini expansion by themselves, instead of packaged with all these superfluous materials and mechanics that detract from the base game.

item.name: Railroad Ink: Blazing Red Edition
item.comment:
See thoughts on the base game under Blue Edition. This comment is for the modules included:
Railroad Ink with some weird chaos variants thrown in. The meteors are kind of charming and don't feel too terrible because of the point bonuses, but (like the Lake in the Blue Edition), the Lava is an ugly and confusing board-filling effect that just gets in the way of meaningful route planning. Both modules also feel expectedly unthematic, and kind of undermine the small amount of class the original edition had.

item.name: Railroad Ink: Deep Blue Edition
item.comment:
Another roll-n-write. I hate to suggest that an entire genre of games is incapable of being great (or even good), but when it is this [i]fundamentally[/i] solitaire it's hard to feel any other way.
That aside, the network building puzzle in the base game of Railroad Ink was interesting at first, but became flat and samey after just a few plays. Scores are remarkably consistent and hover right around 50, with only exceedingly good fortune allowing for much higher.
The modules included in the Blue edition aren't enough to save it either. The River is okay, as it contributes to route building and feels thematic, but the Lake is a confusing mess that looks ugly on the board due to nonsensical open ends and is far too hard to plan around.

item.name: Red7
item.comment: After returning to this with 2 players and with all the advanced rules and optional action rules, I have to admit that there's actually a pretty nifty card game in here. Feels classic and new at the same time, and rarely goes longer than ten minutes.

item.name: Reef Encounter
item.comment: Curious blending of tile-laying and asset evaluation, with a fun theme. The spatial puzzle and "market" aren't as deep or as tight as they are in other more focused games, but Reef Encounter manages to strike a remarkable, playful balance in juggling its systems.

item.name: Regicide
item.comment: Interesting as a sort of case study in how to make the most of a component restriction (a standard deck of playing cards), but otherwise pretty dry and pretty repetitive. The suit powers also feel inappropriately skewed towards diamonds; their untimely absence can be an arbitrary death-knell.

item.name: Res Arcana
item.comment: Another resounding hit from Lehmann that I severely underrated after my first few plays. Snappy, synergistic, and satisfyingly coarse-grained in its tempo and resource management. Fine stuff, but not quite as interactive or expansive as Race for the Galaxy.

item.name: The Resistance
item.comment: Simple hidden role game with no player elimination. That alone made this my go to for a long time when I needed this type of game.

item.name: Ricochet Robots
item.comment: Mentally demanding communal puzzle that is played almost entirely in the players' heads. A singular design that doesn't appeal to everyone, but remains one of the most unique games in my collection.

item.name: Roads & Boats
item.comment:
Strange, exuberant maximalism that feels at once horribly dated and delightfully timeless.
Roads & Boats now finds itself in the uncomfortable position of being compared to modern digital logistics games (Factorio) that have taken this conversion-supply-chain framework to dizzying heights, but there is something so tactile and immediately wonderful about the act of playing R&B that keeps it from feeling obsolete, and its thematic touches are endlessly endearing.
It's the definition of a hot mess, and I simply adore it.

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
item.comment: I'm not sure what it was exactly, but this was one of the hardest games I have ever had to learn due to its complexity (and this is coming from someone who is very much in to heavier stuff). The thematic detail might be admirable, but the exception-ridden ruleset creates an unpleasant mental overload, all in service of an unnecessarily demanding resource shuffler.

item.name: Root
item.comment:
Root's puritanical devotion to asymmetry is interesting and unique, but does come at the cost of clarity and ease of play.
Once everyone is up to speed, Root is fierce and tactical, but the overhead required to reach that point for four separate players (playing four separate games) is enormous, and is almost fatally exacerbated by differences in player experience or gaps between plays. I didn't really understand this until I taught Root to three brand new players having already played several times myself. It felt like a different game.
Despite that though, Root is a remarkable experience when everyone is on the same page.

item.name: Root: The Underworld Expansion
item.comment: Solid additions. Factions fit right in thematically and mechanically, and the new maps offer some much needed spatial variety to the base game.

item.name: Royal Visit
item.comment: Lavishly produced, but I am unconvinced that this has any meaningful or interesting decisions regarding hand management or character movement. Winning with King positioning seems rare, which feels thematically imbalanced and doesn't make the most of the Court's somewhat compelling spatial restrictions. Most games seem decided by who is lucky enough to abuse the high-variance movement of the Wizard and Jester to farm crown points. Weak showing from Knizia.

item.name: Sagrada
item.comment: Yet another little solitaire placement game that is...fine. Damningly so.

item.name: Samurai
item.comment:
Undeniably striking in its presentation, but fairly mild in play. The non-polygonal board seems fascinating at first, but the rigidity of the tile laying means the spatial restriction is mostly meaningless. Tiles mostly stay right where they are and fights for victory tokens become heavily localized, overly tactical little squabbles.
The end game scoring is also so coarse-grained that games often seem decided by thin, unsatisfying tie-breakers. While some games like The King is Dead have managed to make this scoring work, it feels very wooden here. Maybe it’s the insistence on hidden scoring when token majorities are simple to calculate.
My opinion of Samurai might be far higher if I had played it back in the day, but I think it has been entirely eclipsed by more modern designs that follow a similar game-arc, like The King is Dead or Babylonia especially.

item.name: San Marco
item.comment:
Light, zesty area majority game with clear inspirational ties to El Grande. The core “I cut, you choose” mechanism is implemented very well here, and it has meaningful subtleties with balancing short-term and long-term point payoffs. It also happens to look quite pretty.
But It can be somewhat prone to over-analysis when it comes to distributing cards, which can balloon the playtime heavily, and its extremely restrictive player count keeps it from being tabled as much as it deserves; this is a three player game, no more and no less.
Small house rules: player order for choosers simply rotates every round rather than being randomized, and the Banishment action removes a fixed number of cubes: a regular d6 is just far too swingy, if this had a custom die of 3-3-3-4-4-5 I'd keep it in, cause I like the risk management aspect of the action.

item.name: Santiago
item.comment: A fine classic euro with some toothsome denial and negotiation, but a little too rigid in its board development thanks to the multiplicative scoring causing insanely strong incentives to create big, uninteresting groups of like crops, even for those with a minority yield. The watering system might also be a little too "do or die" for my tastes, especially in the last round when crops will dry to completion and the canal overseer position becomes exceedingly powerful.

item.name: Santorini
item.comment: The dimensionality of the system is so unique and I'm sure there is significant depth here, but I was lukewarm after a few plays despite wanting to love it. I just never got that distinctive mind-buzz feeling I get with good abstracts.

item.name: Say Anything
item.comment:
Ahhh, Cards Against Humanities, Apples to Apples; thou shall be surrendered to the flames.
Now for the elephant in the room: this really is just a worse version of Quiplash (which would be an easy 9 from me were it on BGG). Say Anything is still a serviceable cardboard proxy for the system though, even if it’s prompts are occasionally lame and too pop-culture oriented.

item.name: Scarabya
item.comment: It's a thinker, and expands on the "surrounding territory"" variety of polyomino puzzle with variable board setups. A serviceable solitaire filler, but that's all.

item.name: Scattergories
item.comment:
Well...the time has come. I have finally found the inner strength to admit to myself how mediocre Scattergories is. I have been a long-time defender of this game because of fond memories, but the joy I was finding in here for the salesmanship of bad or surreal answers to prompts is now better found in games like Quiplash or Say Anything without all the headache-inducing letter nonsense.
I'll also maintain that the alliteration bonus in Scattergories is one of the worst rules in all of gaming; it incentivizes ridiculous and unfunny strings of barely related words that work against whatever lightheartedness was left in this box.

item.name: SCOUT
item.comment: A crystal clear card game design that can seem insurmountably restrictive on a first play, but reveals wonderful subtlety and depth of control with practice. This may very well become an all-time classic filler.

item.name: Scrabble
item.comment: It's a classic, and as long as no one in your family takes it too seriously, it's still fun.

item.name: Scythe
item.comment: I think I want to enjoy this more than I do. The hybrid euro-combat seems interesting, and occasionally hits, but I wish that combat was either less costly or less directly correlated with earning stars to encourage players to actually interact in the middle of the game, rather than stand around waiting to rush for two assured victories to close things out.

item.name: Scythe: Invaders from Afar
item.comment: Nice additional factions. I really like that they have a clear focus on territory control, but the traps and flags are so unique compared to the other factions that they don't really blend seamlessly into the base game, despite their symbols being preprinted on the board.

item.name: The Search for Planet X
item.comment:
Well this is just delightful. The paper publishing mechanic isn't quite as bluffy or risky as I anticipated, but the puzzle and the presentation is wonderful.
This is a great example of how to use a companion app well: it speeds up learning, speeds up play, and vastly improves the solo experience. Allowing players to play on different difficulty levels in the same game is a brilliant touch. Other games could benefit from a polished helper app like this.

item.name: Sequence
item.comment: It was fine with the grandparents as a kid, but even with the glow and glory of youth I still remember this being fairly uninteresting. This is one of those games whose success depended on its reimplementation of standard card deck symbology, which made it more accessible to an older audience, but alienating to a younger one. Could be a candidate for a makeover into a modern family euro with some art and thematic coating.

item.name: Sidereal Confluence
item.comment:
A cacophony of one-upmanship with an appropriately schlocky sci-fi facade. There is friction, humor, and good-natured suspicion lurking behind every hasty, poorly planned deal, and the factions play off of each other (and the players themselves) in unexpected ways.
The experience of playing Sidereal Confluence is exhausting and exhilarating and certainly fun, but its inherent complexity seems to be fighting against the wheel-and-deal nature of the game. I worry that at high levels it might lose its irreverent charm.

item.name: Skull
item.comment: One of the purest and most accessible bluffing games. While it takes some general player experience to get Poker and Perudo to shine, new players can start getting into the weeds with Skull inside of 10 minutes. I've seen it happen with serious gamers and with half drunk strangers at parties; it never misses.

item.name: Sleuth
item.comment: Randomly restricting the questions you can ask other players feels like a totally unnecessary limitation, and Sleuth falls into the same kind of private, hunched spreadsheet studying that Clue does.

item.name: Space Base
item.comment: Mildly amusing game of assembling a custom craps payout table. It thankfully supported some out-there strategies, but was too solitaire to ever care about anyone else's arrangements. I also have a particular distaste for Space Base's anodyne cartoon art style.

item.name: Spirit Island
item.comment: Polished to a mirror shine. Rewards thoughtful turn planning and punishes tunnel vision. This is head and shoulders above any other cooperative game I've played, but it still feels best as a solo game, which is always a bit of a bummer.

item.name: Spirit Island: Branch & Claw
item.comment: Good expansion for a great game. The event deck pushes players towards a more tactical, intuitive playstyle, which I enjoy, and the new board tokens open up some interesting design space for the new spirits, but it all comes at the small cost of a more cluttered board and a more cluttered headspace. Spirit Island's clarity suffers slightly as a result, but my opinion might change as I grow more accustomed to the effects of the new systems.

item.name: Spirit Island: Promo Pack 1
item.comment: I love how weird these spirits are. They play like nothing else in the base game and are really challenging to play well, even for an experienced player.

item.name: Stephenson's Rocket
item.comment:
A fascinating area majority game masquerading as a cube rail (though it curiously predates the genre by quite a few years). Veto rounds foster a wonderfully parasitic relationship between shareholders, and the possibility of disastrous rail line isolation or consolidation gives these rounds some considerable teeth. One of Knizia's most opaque and mean-spirited designs, and also one of his best.
I must admit that the first play will be simply miserable for most new players; the monopolistic game-arc is almost impossible to envision without seeing it play out first hand, so first impressions of Stephenson's Rocket may be vey poor.

item.name: Sumatra
item.comment:
Welp, this one is just painful now. After getting a chance to try Ra and seeing where Sumatra's design DNA came from, this isn't just the mind-numbingly uninteresting experience I thought it was in isolation, it's a clumsy and ill-conceived maiming of a great game.
The shared board is little more than a round tracker with a single, vapid "stay or go" decision conducting the point-to-point movement, and instead of the dramatic and soulful push-your-luck of the lot creation in Ra, each location visited here represents an utterly, shamefully dry drafting round, with all the same set-collection point sources ported over directly, minus the fun disaster tiles.
With the new reprint of Ra coming into production, this game should simply not exist.

item.name: Sushi Go!
item.comment: Cute but thoughtless little drafting game where the point-per-card values seem horribly skewed towards rewarding simplistic plays over higher risk set building. Underwhelming even by filler standards.

item.name: Taj Mahal
item.comment:
The auctions have some teeth, and I appreciate the shades of chicken and trick taking that come through in the card play. However, the rewards to be gained from these bidding rounds are mostly unimaginative set collection pieces whose value is entirely transparent. The one exception takes place on the board, where careful network building and look-ahead is required to score for the temples. The issue is that the route building involved is difficult to coordinate and the rewards for doing so are almost always strictly worse than just getting another elephant token or whatever. Taj Mahal squandered its one interesting spatial feature, and the board ends up feeling like an afterthought as a result.
Besides that (admittedly personal) shortcoming, I still can't find much to love in Taj Mahal. The card play feels a little too automatic and the "game of chicken" feeling I mentioned earlier can sometimes feel like a far less interesting war of attrition in key regions. Games also seem to consistently run close to 90 minutes, which for what it offers feels about 30 minutes too long.

item.name: Taluva
item.comment: Terse positional jockeying with a stunningly gorgeous production; Taluva is everything I could ever want out of an austere multiplayer abstract. And I mean, come on, just [i]look[/i] at the damn thing.

item.name: TAMSK
item.comment:
What wasted potential. Using hourglasses as playing pieces is such a unique idea, and TAMSK has striking table presence, but aside from the temporal gimmick TAMSK is a flat and tedious combinatorial game. Turns feel automatic, blocking is all but impossible, and move restrictions only become relevant after several dozen busywork moves around the outside of the board. Move place move place move place move place bleh.
I was hoping that TAMSK would be a hidden gem, a game that went tragically under-appreciated in its day, that I could singlehandedly rescue from the archives with my infallible, discerning taste.
It’s not. This was rightfully dropped from the GIPF project, and isn’t worth revisiting. The people were right on this one.

item.name: Terra Mystica
item.comment:
A hefty but sleek euro of parasitic spatial influence and efficiency races. The ebb and flow of the power wheel is the standout mechanic, and the faction asymmetries ensure tactical variety. It’s a good game, simple as that.
I can’t help but dislike the implementation of the cult track; it’s the only element of the design that feels tacked on to me, and it makes the whole package feel less focused. I wish that the priests / elements were integrated into the main board state instead of relegated to such an uninteresting tracking board. It’s by no means fatal to the experience, but I feel it may have been a missed opportunity.

item.name: Terra Nova
item.comment: This just [i]keeps[/i] revealing unexpected subtlety and finesse with every new game, and plays wonderfully with two or three players, though the texture of each is appropriately distinct. A resounding, whip-smart, concentrated euro-abstract that is criminally underrated.

item.name: Terraforming Mars
item.comment:
A fiercely and profoundly unremarkable card-based tableau builder that has somehow wormed its way to the top of the charts.
A big chunk of the deck and most of the standard projects do nothing more than nudge a cube up a track. Engine building effects (aside from income increases) and emergent combos are vanishingly rare. There is very little sense of growing complexity aside from having a bit more money to throw around in the later turns.
I'm not a fan of how few cards you are offered per game, especially when so many are hyper-specific in their use cases. The beginning of each generation usually becomes a tiring exercise of turning down a small pool of obviously useless cards, and there are even games where some players are implicitly disqualified from winning because they never saw any of the condition-less cards that are desperately needed in the early game. It's rare, but not rare enough for a game of this length.
Fans will say that the drafting variant helps this by increasing the number of cards you see per game, but relying on an advanced variant that slows the game down to a crawl to only somewhat fix a central issue feels lame.
And despite everyone playing on a shared board, spatial player interaction is almost nonexistent, and the board state has no meaningful connection to the card tableaus aside from some cursory special tile placements. The board mostly feels like a big VP tracker.
Even the interesting theme has been corporatized into depressing staleness. There are older and newer games in this genre that look better, play better, and cost less. Seventy bucks for TM on the BGG shop is insane.

item.name: Terraforming Mars: Hellas & Elysium
item.comment: New boards are fine (and the new awards & milestones are more than welcome), but they do nothing to fix the central issues I have with TM.

item.name: Through the Desert
item.comment: Solid heads-up euro of juggling priorities, blocking tactics and Go-like territory control. Another great game from Knizia's early catalog.

item.name: Tic-Tac-Toe
item.comment: Only valuable as a pedagogical tool, nothing more.

item.name: Tigris & Euphrates
item.comment: Timeless, ardent beauty. A game of destruction and reformation and fluidity that I could simply play forever.

item.name: Tikal
item.comment: Another good game from Kramer/Kiesling. The communal graph building through the jungle, area majority jockeying, and management of scoring timing are all compelling. The auctions in the advanced variant felt a little flat. I'm not sure they're necessary.

item.name: Titan
item.comment:
I tried lying to myself, and it worked for a while, but after mulling over a dozen digital plays and a few in person plays I've had to accept the fact that Titan just isn't what I want it to be. The promise of epic, 80's-style fantasy warfare was just too intoxicating I guess.
Most of Titan's runtime is consumed by a painfully laborious process of moving your stacks of cardboard chits to gather more cardboard chits, a process that manages to be both unrelentingly calculational due to the complexity of the master board and muster chart, and overwhelmingly arbitrary because of the roll-to-move system. Sure, an expert player may be able to maneuver across the board and muster units with stunning, graceful odds-mitigation, but for any ordinary human being these turns will be arduous and tremendously long as you figure out what the hell the game will allow you to do this turn. It doesn't help that so much of this is dependent on memory, as Titan gives you almost nothing to track what units are in what legion beyond a cutesy symbol; every one of your half dozen legions will have to be picked up and fiddled with every turn, and it's a pain in the ass.
Occasionally, though, the monotony is broken by a tactical little dice-chucking mini game that unfortunately only involves two players at a time. Everyone else just has to sit around and get their thumbs a-twiddling for the twenty or thirty minutes it may take for those two idiots to stop having fun. The whole concept of "zooming-in" on the board and resolving a battle as a sub-game is undeniably exciting, but when put into practice with actual humans sitting at the table it becomes immediately apparent how absurd the suggestion is, and how laughably dated.
Putting aside the logistical concern of leaving half the table unable to play the game, the actual tactics on the battle boards are fairly interesting, though it is extremely disappointing that the personalities of the fantasy creatures are abstracted away to just two number values; no special abilities or thematic asymmetry here, just more dice or a slightly higher hit percentage. You work [i]so[/i] hard to claw your way up the muster chart to recruit these colossal beasts; having that effort be rewarded with just a slightly larger integer is more than a little deflating.
And all of this will take [i]hours[/i] and [i]hours[/i]. Maybe if I had grown up in the 80's and had all the time in the world to blow on playing Titan I would understand why this is so adored by so many, but I didn't, and I don't. Sorry Titan, I loved the idea of you.

item.name: Torres
item.comment:
Sweet, precise, and visually delightful classic euro with meaningful entanglement of player positions. The dimensionality of the castles and the rules for knight movement provide a surprisingly evocative thematic coating.
Really only comes into its own with the Master variant (open action cards), but I'm not convinced that the Master Cards themselves are good for the game; the point swings are often big enough that the card effectively reads "If you do not complete this goal, you lose the game". My preferred version of Torres would probably be open action cards, no Master Cards, highest -> lowest score for turn order in a round. Maybe that's a bit of a Frankenstein, but I think the spirit of the game is still there.

item.name: Town Center
item.comment:
This might be the first true three-dimensional board game I’ve played; the merging and separation of groups of cubes in vertical space is enticing, and I appreciate Town Center’s commitment to the unintuitive paradigm.
However, something feels sort of [i]wrong[/i] with the design. The money to point conversion is so abysmal that any arduous attempts at milking buildings for income throughout the game are completely overwhelmed by residential scoring, and the money itself is used for very little else.
The merging of residential units into large scoring groups becomes the sole strategic outlook of Town Center, and those mergers are dependent on a very limited supply of offices, which often end up unevenly distributed amongst the players for no good reason, and which require a strange $5 payment that seems to only ever matter when screwing over an arbitrarily poor player in the early rounds. The control given to the first player to secure/deny any drawn offices through the cube draft also feels…off.
I think this may have needed some more development time to find the game in here, cause it’s got good spatial bones.

item.name: Townsfolk Tussle
item.comment: Bog-standard boss battler with only a charming aesthetic to keep it from being completely unnoteworthy. The artistic direction and sculpting on the minis is sincerely wonderful, but that can't possibly be enough to justify the existence of monstrous, shallow games like this.

item.name: Trains
item.comment:
A pretty derivative fusion of the Dominion card engine and a Winsome cube rail map. The numbers have been quite literally lifted straight out of those other games.
I wouldn't play this over Dominion, and I wouldn't play this over a cube rail. Why does this exist?

item.name: Trek 12: Himalaya
item.comment:
My first roll-and-write. Some clever use of dice probabilities, and some decent summit variations, but the puzzle isn't interesting or challenging enough to make up for the complete lack of interaction.
The system is so simple and the course of play is so lonely that a game of Trek 12 feels more like a back-of-the-magazine brain teaser than a board game you sit down to play with (gasp) [i]other people[/i]. This makes all those sad, beige euros that people love to rag on for being multiplayer solitaire look like wargames.
I'm worried that the whole roll-and-write genre might be similarly reclusive.

item.name: Twilight Struggle
item.comment:
While the detail and potential for skilled play are readily apparent, I came out of my first half-dozen games severely let down. ______________________________________________________
The rawness of the tug-of-war system for controlling countries resulted in a lot of unsatisfying tit-for-tat exchanges during play and the consolidation of so much geopolitical subtlety into abstract Influence Points made TS feel unexpectedly disconnected from its theme. After just a few rounds the Cold War veneer washed away and all I saw was a board of red and blue numbers and a bunch of red and white cards that made the numbers go up or down. It feels gamey.
This unfortunate feeling was further enhanced by the event system. Forcing events of the opposite player to trigger when a card is used for OPs seemed intriguing at first, but it ended up making my games feel disappointingly similar. With almost every event being forced to go off sooner or later, and with player's having such limited agency in their three actions (really two, accounting for the dubious balance of realignment), it just didn't seem possible to have any drastic narrative departures, and the overall game-feel was one of complete mercy to the deck.
Not only does this make TS's narrative arc too scripted for my tastes, but it also means that high levels of play in TS seem dependent on deck memorization and careful maneuvering around the specific requirements of your opponent's events. Encouraging this type of hyper-detailed foreknowledge is personally unsatisfying as a player, but also undermines TS's thematic bedrock: that the Cold War (to the best of my understanding) was a cultural epoch defined largely by crippling [i]un[/i]certainty. ______________________________________________________
Most of all though, I [i]heavily[/i] dislike the type of dice randomness that TS employs. The probabilities of each roll are transparent and drama-less, and the only two possible outcomes for any scenario usually boil down to a painfully binary yes or no. If you roll badly on a space-race discard, you just don't make any progress at all (cause everybody knows rocket scientists are prone to just winging it). If you roll badly on a Quagmire/Bear Trap check, you just [i]don't play the game[/i] until you roll better. The dice don't become a source of tactical reassessment or granular risk management, they just get in the way and become a depressing parental lock. Coups are the notable exception to this, as the rewards gained are determined by the strength of the roll, something I wish more effects in TS would have emulated.
With the combination of so many binary die rolls and the variance in the card deck, the likelihood of playing a non-game of TS seems to be worryingly high. Someone got all the neutral 4-OP cards the first time through the deck, or someone had to sit out for four (or nine in one of our games) rounds due to Quagmire, or just the right scoring cards randomly came back out of the late war deck to favor one player over another. I'm sure that in the aggregate, strong TS players win more often than not, but this level of wild unpredictability is not easy to accept when games can be 3+ hours long. ______________________________________________________
One last gamey nail in the coffin: having the active player be the sole loser in the event of Nuclear Holocaust is ridiculous. It creates insane incentives for one player to enact mutually assured destruction on their opponent's turn if possible because even if you pull the trigger, you can still die a winner off a technicality.

item.name: TZAAR
item.comment: A lit firecracker. The giddy, coked-out younger brother of the GIPF series that doesn't have a non-aggressive bone in its body. Maybe it's imbalanced, it might even be outright silly at times, but I've rarely had more fun with an abstract game.

item.name: Tzolk'in: The Mayan Calendar
item.comment: All the usual heavy euro fare: worker placement, point optimization, some engine-building effects, nudging little circles up tracks; but with an uncharacteristic amount of strategic look-ahead required to move through the systems efficiently due to the rotating gears and the place/pull mechanism for assigning workers.

item.name: Underwater Cities
item.comment:
This shares so much DNA with games I usually dislike, but through some arcane design magic I actually had a good time with Underwater Cities.
Emergent combos are frequent and satisfying, deck penetration is tuned well, the Era decks ensure a good game flow, and the color coded action system and tight worker placement made turns tense. You can include me in the camp of people who think this is Terraforming Mars done right.

item.name: Unfathomable
item.comment:
Unfathomable feels like a 45 minute Arkham Horror TCG scenario stretched to a mind-numbing four hour runtime. I understand that the Battlestar Galactica implementation has a significant pedigree, but I can't see myself ever wanting to try any version of this system again. This was skill checks upon skill checks upon skill checks to claw and crawl your way towards the end condition, with the added bureaucratic complications of dealing with random traitorous players.
I could see myself digging this with a hard 90 minute playtime, but sadly that's just not what these games are. I don't even think the game looks all that great; the board is unassuming and mostly empty space and the minis (aside from the Mother) look a little goofy to me.

item.name: UNO
item.comment: It's really just an activity that fills in any awkward gaps in conversation at a family reunion. You can turn your brain off and just play a card. I guess it deserves a little love for introducing me to non-standard card games at such a young age.

item.name: Viticulture Essential Edition
item.comment: Something feels missing. It has some solid systems and a satisfying little chain of resources, but it just doesn't...do anything. No soul.

item.name: Viticulture: Tuscany Essential Edition
item.comment:
One step forward, more than a few steps back. The new wake up track is the only significant improvement for me. Everything else is some flavor of bloat that works to dilute what little Viticulture had going for it in the first place.
As soulless as the base game was, its tight, satisfying resource chain of vines to grapes to wine to orders to points was well crafted. Tuscany chips away at that completeness by providing too many opportunities to score points at each step of that process. I appreciate that this was done to address the luck factor present in the base game, but I feel its a net loss.
By opening up the board to a full four seasons the threat of competition for worker spaces has been almost completely removed. That was the one, small piece of player interaction Viticulture had, and it is further degraded by the addition of the special workers, which often break placement rules.
And the new star token area control mini-game is easily one of the most incongruous and tacked on expansion modules I've ever seen. It's a completely bizarre addition that has been woven into the new action spaces, so it's impossible to leave out like the other modules. A baffling and distracting inclusion.

item.name: War Chest
item.comment:
Fairly delicate balance of tactics and pool building, with an interesting central conceit of strengthening a unit by sacrificing its action potential. However, the intelligent tactics afforded by the pieces is quickly overwhelmed by the variance of the coins.
High quality production aside from one glaring graphic design oversight (coins cover control icons entirely, could have used a green border).

item.name: War of the Ring: Second Edition
item.comment:
A sprawling, strategic sandbox whose heartbreaking thematic vividness and agonizing mechanical tension makes for a totally engrossing, almost overwhelming experience. It might not capture the real literary essence of LOTR, but it has significantly deepened my appreciation for the depth and breadth of Tolkien's world.
That would be an impressive feat for a book written by a Tolkien scholar. For a board game? Unthinkable.

item.name: Wavelength
item.comment: This requires you to know something about the people you're playing with, so with strangers it falls flat in ways that Decrypto or Codenames doesn't, but for families and close friends it's almost unbeatable. For me it has never failed to foster interesting discussions about a person's psychological biases, but in a way that is always good-natured and never antagonistic.

item.name: What Do You Meme?
item.comment: Another “be funny in OUR way” game, but with a sanitized meme-culture veneer that gives off a really intense vibe of trying way too hard to be cool. The task of translating a cultural motif that [i]intrinsically[/i] derives it’s humor and interest from rapid modification into the static world of cardboard was doomed from the start. The moment the ink hit the paper, the cards were already out of date.

item.name: Wingspan
item.comment:
The production is very pretty, but the gameplay is dreary and lacking in many decisions. Most everyone's tableau feels distant and samey, and there aren't enough tools to influence the type of engine you build. You just make the best tactical decision every turn and see what the game allows you to do.
Even so, in all my games, no matter what general structure of tableau any player has created, laying eggs consistently becomes the most efficient way to score points near the end of the game for everyone. It's a shame because the eggs are the least interesting mechanism in this whole box, they shouldn't be the main focus of the last few rounds.

item.name: Witness
item.comment: Not what I wanted it to be. Very little silliness and very few laughs; the cases are so dependent on silent concentration and rote memory that the inherent joy of the "Telephone" structure is lost in all the logic. Witness is trying to be both a cerebral deduction game and a lighthearted party game, and for me it failed at being either.

item.name: XCOM: The Board Game
item.comment:
A tasteless, administrative adaptation of a great tactical skirmish game.
The real-time elements feel unfaithful to the original and attempt to manufacture some shallow tension for the upkeep tasks of each round. The game would be entirely unchanged if these steps were performed in turn order.
XCOM (the video game) always maintained an intense and emergent sense of identity for each soldier, each mission, and each playthrough through its wonderful intersection of probabilities, but these have been reduced to near meaninglessness in the board game. The nail-biting odds manipulation of the original has been crudely rendered with an unimaginative push-your-luck dice mechanism, soldiers are faceless, nameless units without any defining mechanical traits, missions are little more than a list of icons and rewards, and the progressive gameplay arc is undermined by the random, unresponsive card decks.
I respect some of the interplay between the player roles, but the separation of all these game elements amongst four player leaves me feeling like I'm only ever playing 1/4th of a complete experience. And that experience is widely available on multiple digital platforms for half the price!
This is yet [i]another[/i] game that has been released in the last ten years that feels to me like it is recklessly and needlessly struggling against the constraints of the medium, and I'm forced to ask myself the same tired question: why am I not just playing a video game?

item.name: YINSH
item.comment: Perhaps the cleanest and most approachable of the GIPF games, but no less cunning and certainly no less dynamic. After finally seeing my way through the whole series, my opinion of its poster child has stayed unexpectedly high. This is still a wonderful abstract, and its mechanism for equalizing the players after a point is scored feels like the holy grail of a game rule: like it was [i]discovered[/i] rather than designed.

item.name: Zendo
item.comment: It's such a pure, fundamental design; it feels ancient. The little bubble of inductive inquiry that Zendo creates at the table is a beautiful, sacred thing.

item.name: ZÈRTZ
item.comment:
The most physically beautiful of all its beautiful siblings; any unfamiliar passersby would not be at fault for assuming the players were simply appreciating an abstract work of art someone had left at the table, rather than playing a game.
Forcing captures from your opponent to set up your own future captures is ZERTZ's fascinating, vivid core idea, and because these forced captures result in your opponent necessarily gaining [i]something[/i] in the process, the game becomes a taut struggle of maximizing your gains while minimizing your opponent's against a shared, scarce supply of resources. Dear lord, Is this an economic game in disguise?
